Donato Bramante

(1480--1519) What Italian noblewoman was the illegitimate daughter of Pope Alexander VI and sister of Cesare?
Lucrezia Borgia

(1485--1547) What first Spanish conquistador overthrew the Aztec empire by conquering its capital, Tenochtitlán, in 1519 and by deposing its emperor, Montezuma, and annihilated Tenochtitlán in 1521, established Mexico City as the capital of New Spain, and served briefly as its governor?
Hernando Cortés

(1488--1568) What English biblical scholar translated the first complete printed English Bible in 1535?
Miles Coverdale

(1491--1557) What French explorer was the first to establish France's claim to North America, making three voyages to Canada between 1534 and 1541?
Jacques Cartier

(1509--64) On becoming a Protestant, this theologian and reformer fled to Switzerland, where he attempted to reorder society on reformed Christian principles. Identify this Frenchman whose Institutes of the Christian Religion (1536) was the first systematic account of reformed Christian doctrine.
John Calvin

(1546--1601) What Danish astronomer built an observatory equipped with precision instruments and, despite demonstrating that comets follow sun-centred paths, adhered to a geocentric system of planetary motions?
Tycho Brahe

(1548--1600) What Italian philosopher supported the heliocentric Copernican view of the solar system, envisaged an infinite universe of numerous worlds moving in space, and thus was tried by the Inquisition for heresy and burned at the stake?
Giordano Bruno

(1550--1605) This Russian was tsar from 1598 to 1605. Identify this namesake of an opera whose reign was marked by famine, doubts over his involvement in the earlier death of Ivan the Terrible's eldest son, and the appearance of pretender False Dmitri.
Boris Godunov

(1564--93) What English poet and playwright wrote works including The Jew of Malta, Doctor Faustus, Edward the Second, and The massacre at Paris?
Christopher Marlowe

(1567--1635) What French explorer and colonial statesman established a settlement at Quebec in 1608, developed alliances with the indigenous peoples, and was appointed lieutenant governor in 1612?
Samuel de Champlain

(1585--1638) What Flemish theologian and Roman Catholic strongly opposed the Jesuits and proposed reform of Christianity through a return to the teachings of St. Augustine, founding a movement that bears his name?
Cornelius Otto Jansen

(1593--c. 1661) What English-born Dutch portrait painter painted for the court of Charles I and, after the outbreak of the English Civil War, emigrated to Holland (1643)?
Cornelius Johnson

(1599--1667) This Italian architect was a ``keen student of the architecture of Michelangelo and the ruins of Antiquity.'' Identify this leading figure of the Italian baroque style whose most notable works include the Re Magi Chapel of the Propaganda Fide, Sant'Agnese in Agone, Sant'Ivo alla Sapienza, the Oratory of Saint Philip Neri, and San Carlo alle Quattro Fontane.
Francesco Borromini

(1600--82) What French painter is noted for the use of light in his landscapes, his works including Ascanius and the stag (1682)?
Claude Lorrain

(1606--84) What French playwright, regarded as the founder of classical French tragedy, composed Le Cid (1637), Cinna (1641), and Polyeucte (1643)?
Pierre Corneille

(1612--80) What English poet is most notable for his three-part satirical poem Hudibras (1663--78)?
Samuel Butler

(1625--1712) What Italian-born French astronomer discovered the gap in the rings of Saturn, which are named after him?
Giovanni Domenico Cassini

(1628--88) What English writer's major work, The pilgrim's progress (1678--84), is an allegory recounting the spiritual journey of its hero Pilgrim?
John Bunyan

(1628--1703) What French writer is noted for Mother goose tales (1697)?
Charles Perrault

(1643--87) What French explorer sailed from Canada down the Ohio and Mississippi rivers to the Gulf of Mexico in 1682, naming the Mississippi basin Louisiana in honour of Louis XIV and, in 1684, led an expedition to establish a French colony on the Gulf of Mexico, but was murdered when his followers mutinied?
René-Robert Cavelier La Salle

(1670--1729) What English playwright's plays, such as Love for love (1695) and The way of the world (1700), epitomize the wit and satire of Restoration comedy?
William Congreve

(1682--1718) What king of Sweden (1697--1718) initiated the Great Northern War against Denmark, Poland-Saxony, and Russia in 1700 and embarked on an expedition into Russia in 1709, which ended in the destruction of his army and his internment?
Charles XII

(1695--1755) What British soldier was commander in chief of the British forces in America and died in action in western Pennsylvania?
Edward Braddock

(1703--70) What French painter, decorative artist, and leading figure of the rococo style in France is known for works like The rising of the sun (1753) and Summer pastoral (1749)?
François Boucher

(1707--78) What Swedish botanist and founder of modern systematic botany and zoology devised an authoritative classification system for flowering plants involving binomial Latin names (later superseded by that of Antoine Jussieu) and a classification method for animals?
Carolus Linnaeus

(1707--88) What French naturalist and founder of paleontology emphasized the unity of all living species, minimizing the apparent differences between animals and plants, and wrote a compilation of the animal kingdom, the Histoire Naturelle, which reached thirty-six volumes by the time of his death?
Comte de Buffon

(1713--84) What French philosopher, writer, critic, and leading figure of the French Enlightenment was principal editor of the Encyclopédie (1751--76) and composed works such as Le Rêve de D'Alembert (1782) and Le Neveu de Rameau (1805)?
Denis Diderot

(1714--87) What German composer initiated a new style in which he united dramatic, musical, and emotional elements with Orfeo ed Euridice (1762), revolutionizing opera, and composed Alceste (1767), Iphigénie en Aulide (1774), and Iphigénie en Tauride (1779)?
Christoph Willibald Gluck

(1716--83) What English landscape gardener evolved an English style of natural-looking landscape parks and has work enduring at Belvoir Castle, Croome Court, Blenheim Palace, Warwick Castle, Harewood House, Highclere Castle, Appuldurcombe House, and Milton Abbey?
Lancelot Capability Brown

(1718--79) What English furniture maker and designer produced furniture in a neoclassical vein, with elements of the French rococo, chinoiserie, and Gothic revival styles?
Thomas Chippendale

(1729--1811) What French explorer led the first French circumnavigation of the globe from 1766 to 1769, visiting many of the islands of the South Pacific and compiling an invaluable scientific record of his findings?
Louis Antoine de Bougainville

(1740--95) What Scottish author and companion and biographer of Samuel Johnson wrote Journal of a tour to the Hebrides (1785) and The life of Samuel Johnson (1791)?
James Boswell

(1743--1823) What English engineer invented the power loom?
Edmund Cartwright

(1754--1838) What French statesman became head of the new government after the fall of Napoleon in 1814 and was later instrumental in the overthrow of Charles X and the accession of Louis Philippe in 1830?
Charles de Talleyrand

(1759--96) What Scottish poet is noted for poems such as ``The jolly beggars'' (1786) and ``Tam o' shanter'' (1791), and for old Scottish songs that he collected, including ``Auld Lang Syne''?
Robert Burns

(1760--1825) What French social reformer and philosopher argued that society should be organized by leaders of industry and given spiritual direction by scientists?
Comte de Saint-Simon

(1768--93) What French political assassin assassinated revolutionary leader Jean-Paul Marat in his bath in 1793 and was later found guilty of treason and guillotined four days later?
Charlotte Corday

(1768--1848) What French writer and diplomat is noted for Le Génie du Christianisme (1802) and Mémoires d'outre-tombe (autobiography, 1849--50)?
François-René Chateaubriand

(1770--1838) What American explorer commanded an expedition from 1804 to 1806 across the North American continent with Meriwether Lewis?
William Clark

(1772--1834) What English poet, critic, and philosopher marked the start of English romanticism in his Lyrical ballads (1798), written with William Wordsworth, which included ``The rime of the ancient mariner,'' and also wrote ``Christabel'' and ``Kubla Khan'' (1816)?
Samuel Taylor Coleridge

(1775--1834) What English essayist and critic authored Essays of Elia (1823) and wrote Tales from Shakespeare (1807) with his sister Mary (1764--1847)?
Charles Lamb

(1777--1852) What American politician, statesman, and orator (secretary of state 1825--29), nicknamed ``the Great Pacificator'' and ``the Great Compromiser,'' was a leader of the anti-British ``War Hawks'' in 1811 and championed the Missouri Compromise 1820?
Henry Clay

(1778--1840) What English dandy was the arbiter of British fashion for the early nineteenth century, owing his social position to his friendship with the Prince Regent?
George Bryan Brummell

(1779--1863) What American writer is best known for his poem ``A visit from St. Nicholas'' (1822), which was published anonymously?
Clement Moore

(1780--1831) What Prussian general and military theorist wrote On war (1833), which had a marked influence on strategic studies in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries?
Karl von Clausewitz

(1786--1826) What German composer is regarded as the founder of the German romantic school of opera and wrote Der Freischütz (1817--21) and Euryanthe (1822--23)?
Carl Maria von Weber

(1787--1848) What Irish genealogical and heraldic writer compiled the first edition of a Peerage in 1826, still regarded as the authoritative guide to the British aristocracy?
John Burke

(1795--1881) What Scottish historian and political philosopher wrote History of the French Revolution (1837)?
Thomas Carlyle

(1796--1832) What French scientist's work in analyzing the efficiency of steam engines was crucial to the theory of thermodynamics?
Nicolas Léonard Sadi Carnot

(1797--1858) What Swedish chemist discovered the elements lanthanum, erbium, and terbium, and the supposed element didymium?
Carl Gustaf Mosander

(1805--70) What English engineer and railroad contractor built more than 10,000 kilometres of railroads in Europe, India, South America, and Australia?
Thomas Brassey

(1806--61) What English poet who eloped with Robert in 1846 established her reputation with Poems (1844) and wrote other works like Sonnets from the Portuguese (1850), Aurora Leigh (novel, 1857), and the posthumous Last poems (1862)?
Elizabeth Barrett Browning

(1806--59) What English engineer, son of French-born engineer Sir Marc, designed the Great Western (1838), the first transatlantic steamship, and the Great Eastern (1858), the world's largest ship until 1899?
Isambard Kingdom Brunel

(1811--99) What German chemist pioneered spectroscopy with Kirchhoff, detecting new elements (cesium and rubidium) and determining the composition of many substances and of the sun and stars, and designed chemical apparatuses including his namesake burner (1855)?
Robert Bunsen

(1812--89) What English poet who eloped with Elizabeth Barrett in 1846 established his name with Dramatic lyrics that contained ``The pied piper of Hamelin'' and ``My last duchess'' and wrote other works like Dramatic romances and lyrics (1845), Men and women (1855), and The ring and the book (1868--69)?
Robert Browning

(1817--78) What French landscape painter and member of the Barbizon School is often regarded as a linking figure between this group and the impressionists?
Charles François Daubigny

(1818--93) What French composer, conductor, and organist is best known for his opera Faust (1859)?
Charles François Gounod

(1819--77) What French painter and leader of the nineteenth-century realist school of painting's works include Burial at Ornans (1850) and Painter in his studio (1855)?
Gustave Courbet

(1821--90) This explorer, anthropologist, and translator, along with John Hanning Speke, was the first European to see Lake Tanganyika. Identify this Englishman who translated Arabian nights (1885--88), Kama Sutra (1883), and The perfumed garden (1886)?
Sir Richard Burton

(1821--93) What English painter was inspired by the Pre-Raphaelites, and in 1861 he became a founding member of William Morris's company, designing stained glass and furniture?
Ford Madox Brown

(1822--90) What Belgian-born French composer and organist wrote Symphonic variations for piano and orchestra (1885), the D minor Symphony (1886--88), and the String Quartet (1889)?
César Franck

(1825--93) What French neurologist and founder of modern neurology's work on hysteria was adopted by his student Sigmund Freud?
Jean-Martin Charcot

(1825--95) What English couturier, resident in France from 1845, is regarded as the founder of Parisian haute couture and noted for designing gowns with crinolines and introducing the bustle?
Charles Frederick Worth

(1826--1910) What Italian chemist revived Avogadro's law and used it to distinguish clearly between atoms and molecules and to introduce the unified system of atomic and molecular weights?
Stanislao Cannizzaro

(1828--98) What German botanist and founder of bacteriology was the first to devise a systematic classification of bacteria into genera and species?
Ferdinand Cohn

(1829--1912) What English religious leader founded the Salvation Army and was its first general?
William Booth

(1830--1903) What French painter and graphic artist was a leading figure of the impressionist movement, typically painting landscapes and cityscapes and experimenting with pointillism in the 1880s?
Camille Pissarro

(1832--98) What English writer wrote the children's classics Alice's adventures in wonderland (1865) and Through the looking glass (1871), which were inspired by Alice Liddell, the young daughter of the dean at the Oxford college where he was a mathematics lecturer?
Lewis Carroll

(1832--1910) What French-born American aviation pioneer produced a number of gliders, including a biplane which made over seven hundred flights, and assisted the Wright brothers in making the world's first controlled powered flight?
Octave Chanute

(1833-98) What English painter and designer is noted for painting The mirror of Venus (1873--1877) and The golden stairs (1880)?
Sir Edward Burne-Jones

(1836--1911) What American publisher and manufacturer's board game ``The Checkered Game of Life'' (1860) led to the formation of a company in his name in 1864?
Milton Bradley

(1837--1921) What American naturalist and author entertained friends such as John Muir, Theodore Roosevelt, and Walt Whitman at his home near the Hudson River at West Park, New York, and wrote works including Wake-robin (1871), Locusts and wild honey (1879), and The summit of the years (1913)?
John Burroughs

(1839--1906) What French painter is closely identified with post-impressionism, and his later work had an important influence on cubism, having painted The hanged man's house (1873), Still life with Cupid (1895) and Bathers (sequence of paintings, 1890--1905)?
Paul Cézanne

(1839--1914) What American philosopher, logician, and founder of pragmatism argued that the meaning of a belief is to be understood by the actions and uses to which it gives rise?
Charles Sanders Peirce

(1841--1929) What French statesman (prime minister 1906-09, 1917--20) pushed hard for a punitive settlement with Germany at the Versailles peace talks but failed to obtain all that he demanded?
Georges Clemenceau

(1843--1926) What Italian histologist and anatomist devised a staining technique to investigate nerve tissue, classified types of nerve cells, described the structure in the cytoplasm of most cells now named after him, and won the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine (1906) with Santiago Ramón y Cajal?
Camillo Golgi

(1844--1926) What American painter, known for her draftsmanship, etching, and dry-point studies, was persuaded by Edgar Degas to exhibit with the impressionists, worked mostly in Paris, and painted works, including Lady at the tea table (1885), that display a close interest in everyday subject matter?
Mary Cassatt

(1844--1930) What English poet and literary critic, who was poet laureate from 1913 to 1930, wrote a long philosophical poem, The testament of beauty (1929), in the Victorian tradition?
Robert Bridges

(1845--1918) What Russian-born German mathematician's work on numbers laid the foundations for the theory of sets and stimulated twentieth-century exploration of number theory?
Georg Cantor

(1846--86) After what English graphic artist and watercolour painter, noted for his illustrations for children's books, is an annually-awarded medal for the illustration of American children's books named?
Randolph Caldecott

(1847--1912) What Irish novelist and theatre manager is chiefly remembered as the author of the vampire story Dracula (1897)?
Bram Stoker

(1849--1924) What British-born American novelist is remembered chiefly for her novels for children, including Little Lord Fauntleroy (1886), A little princess (1905), and The secret garden (1911)?
Frances Hodgson Burnett

(1849--1926) What American horticulturist's experiments in cross-breeding led to new types and improved varieties of plants, especially the Shasta daisy and the potato?
Luther Burbank

(1850--1917) What Italian-born American religious leader founded the Missionary Sisters of the Sacred Heart in 1880, was responsible for the establishment of many schools, hospitals, and orphanages in the United States and South America, and became the first American saint in 1946?
St. Frances Xavier Cabrini

(1850--1918) What German physicist who shared the Nobel Prize in 1909 with Marconi invented the coupled system of radio transmission and a forerunner of the cathode ray tube in which a beam of electrons could be deflected?
Karl Ferdinand Braun

(1854--1937) What Canadian Conservative statesman was prime minister (1911--20)?
Robert Laird Borden

(1857--1952) What English physiologist contributed greatly to the understanding of the nervous system and introduced the concept of reflexactions and the reflex arc, having won the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine (1932)?
Sir Charles Scott Sherrington

(1858--1930) What Dutch physician's work resulted in a simple cure for beriberi and led to the discovery of the vitamin thiamine, winning the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine (1929) with Frederick G. Hopkins?
Christiaan Eijkman

(1859--1930) What Scottish novelist and short-story writer is known for his creation of private detective Sherlock Holmes, who first appeared in A study in scarlet (1887), and wrote The hound of the Baskervilles (1902)?
Sir Arthur Conan Doyle

(1860--1917) What German organic chemist studied the chemistry of alcoholic fermentation and identified several enzymes, notably zymase, and won the Nobel Prize for Chemistry (1907)?
Eduard Buchner

(1862--1942) What English physicist and founder of solid-state physics collaborated with his son, Sir (William) Lawrence (1890--1971), in developing X-ray diffraction for determining the atomic structure of crystals and shared the Nobel Prize for Physics with his son in 1915?
Sir William Henry Bragg

(1865--1931) What Danish composer is best known for his six symphonies?
Carl August Nielsen

(1870--1953) What Russian poet, writer, and opponent of modernism concentrated on the themes of peasant life and love and won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1933?
Ivan Bunin

(1870--1961) Belgian bacteriologist and immunologist discovered the complement system of blood serum and developed a vaccine for whooping cough?
Jules Bordet

(1873--1921) What Italian opera singer was the first major tenor whose work was recorded and released on records?
Enrico Caruso

(1874--1936) What English essayist, novelist, and critic's novels include The Napoleon of Notting Hill (1904) and a series of detective stories featuring Father Brown, a priest with a talent for crime detection?
G. K. Chesterton

(1874--1939) What English archaeologist discovered the tomb of Tutankhamen in 1922 while excavating in the Valley of the Kings at Thebes?
Howard Carter

(1874--1954) What American composer, noted for his use of polyrhythms, polytonality, quarter-tones, and aleatoric techniques, wrote works like The unanswered question (1906), Three places in New England (1903--14), and Concord (1915)?
Charles Ives

(1875--1946) What Soviet statesman was head of state (1919--46) and founded the newspaper Pravda (1912)?
Mikhail Ivanovich Kalinin

(1875--1950) What American novelist and science fiction writer was most successful with an adventure series that began with Tarzan of the apes (1914)?
Edgar Rice Burroughs

(1876--1957) What Romanian-born French sculptor's sculpture represents an attempt to move away from representational art and capture the essence of forms by reducing them to their ultimate, almost abstract, simplicity?
Constantin Brancusi

(1878--1965) What Austrian-born Israeli religious philosopher's existentialist work I and thou (1923) argues that religious experience involves reciprocal relationships with a personal subject, rather than knowledge of some ``thing''?
Martin Buber

(1878--1967) This poet and biographer's poetry is collected in Chicago poems (1915), Smoke and steel (1920), Complete poems (1950), and Honey and salt (1963). Identify this American also noted for his biography of Abraham Lincoln, written in six volumes (Abraham Lincoln: The prairie years, two volumes, and Abraham Lincoln: The war years, four volumes) between 1926 and 1939.
Carl Sandburg

(1882--1963) What French painter's collages, which introduced commercial lettering and fragmented objects into pictures to contrast the real with the ``illusory'' painted image, were the first stage in developing synthetic cubism?
Georges Braque

(1884--1942) What Polish anthropologist initiated the technique of participant observation and developed the functionalist approach to anthropology?
Bronisław Malinowski

(1884--1967) What Polish-born American biochemist showed that a number of diseases, including scurvy, rickets, beriberi, and pellagra, were caused by the deficiency of a particular dietary component and coined the term ``vitamins'' for the chemicals concerned?
Casimir Funk

(1887--1985) What Russian-born French painter and graphic artist's work was characterized by the use of rich emotive colour and dream imagery and had a significant influence on surrealism?
Marc Chagall

(1888--1970) What Indian physicist discovered an effect whereby the wavelength of light changes when a light beam is deflected by molecules (named after him), one of the most significant proofs of the quantum theory of light, and won the Nobel Prize for Physics in 1930?
Sir C. V. Raman

(1889--1963) What French playwright, novelist, and movie director's works include Beauty and the beast (1945) and Orpheus (1949)?
Jean Cocteau

(1890--1938) What Czech novelist and playwright is known for R. U. R. (Rossum's universal robots) (1920), which introduced the word ``robot'' to the English language, and The insect play (1921), written with his brother Josef (1887--1945)?
Karel Čapek

(1890--1960) What Russian poet, novelist, and translator is best known for Doctor Zhivago, a story that describes the experience of the Russian intelligentsia during the Russian Revolution that was banned in the former Soviet Union, and had to turn down the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1958?
Boris Pasternak

(1891--1970) What German-born American philosopher and founding member of the Vienna Circle wrote The logical structure of the world (1928) and The logical foundations of probability (1950)?
Rudolf Carnap

(1893--1943) What Lithuanian-born French painter and major exponent of expressionism's early pictures were of grotesque figures, while his later pictures tended to be still lifes?
Chaim Soutine

(1894--1974) What Indian physicist frequently collaborated with Einstein and was a key component in developing quantum and statistical mechanics?
Satyendra Nath Bose

(1897--1945) What German Nazi leader and politician was Hitler's minister of propaganda?
Joseph Goebbels

(1898--1956) This playwright, producer, and poet's interest in combining music and drama led to collaboration with Kurt Weill in The threepenny opera (1928). Identify this German whose later dramas include Mother courage (1941) and The Caucasian chalk circle (1948).
Bertolt Brecht

(1898--1976) What American sculptor and painter, one of the first artists to introduce movement into sculpture, made mobiles incorporating abstract forms and static sculptures called ``stabiles''?
Alexander Calder

(1899--1966) What English novelist is remembered for his seafaring novels set during the Napoleonic Wars and featuring Captain Horatio Hornblower and also for The African queen (1935)?
C. S. Forester

(1899--1973) What British novelist and short-story writer wrote works including The death of the heart (1938) and The heat of the day (1949)?
Elizabeth Bowen

(1899--1973) What English playwright, actor, and composer is remembered for witty, satirical plays, such as Hay fever (1925) and Private lives (1930), as well as for revues and musicals featuring songs such as ``Mad dogs and Englishmen'' (1932)?
Sir Noël Coward

(1899--1981) What American jazz pianist, composer, and singer's best-known songs include ``Stardust'' (1929), ``Georgia on my mind'' (1930), and ``In the cool, cool, cool of the evening'' (1951)?
Hoagy Carmichael

(1899--1986) What Argentine poet, short-story writer, and essayist wrote a seminal work of magic realism: A universal history of infamy (1935)?
Jorge Luis Borges

(1900--83) What Spanish movie director wrote and directed his first movie Un Chien andalou (1929) jointly with Salvador Dalí and directed other films like Belle de jour (1967) and The discreet charm of the bourgeoisie (1972)?
Luis Buñuel

(1901--72) What English yachtsman was the first person to sail alone around the world with only one stop (1966--67) in his yacht Gipsy Moth IV?
Sir Francis Chichester

(1902--81) What Hungarian-born American architect designed the UNESCO headquarters in Paris (1953--58) and the Whitney Museum of American Art in New York City (1963--66) and is also known for his chair designs?
Marcel Lajos Breuer

(1902--87) What American physicist and inventor invented the point-contact transistor with Bardeen and Shockley, for which the three shared the Nobel Prize in 1956?
Walter Houser Brattain

(1903-90) What Austrian-born American psychologist's experiences in Nazi Germany helped him develop revolutionary theories and therapies for autistic children based on Freudian psychoanalysis?
Bruno Bettelheim

(1903--2000) What Tunisian nationalist and statesman was the first president of independent Tunisia (1957--87)?
Habib ibn Ali Bourguiba

(1904--90) What Soviet physicist investigated the effects of high-energy particles, discovered the cause of blue light emitted by radioactive substances underwater, and shared the 1958 Nobel Prize for Physics with Ilja Mikhailovich Frank and Igor Yevgenyevich Tamm?
Pavel Cherenkov

(1904--90) What American behaviourist psychologist promoted the view that the proper aim of psychology should be to predict behaviour and hence be able to control it and applied the results of his studies to the development of programmed learning and educational practice?
Burrhus Frederic Skinner

(1906--45) This German Lutheran theologian was an active opponent of Nazism and was involved in the German resistance. Identify this pastor arrested in 1943, sent to Buchenwald concentration camp, and later executed.
Dietrich Bonhoeffer

(1906--45) This German Lutheran theologian was an active opponent of Nazism and was involved in the German resistance. Identify this pastor arrested in 1943, sent to Buchenwald concentration camp, and later executed.
Dietrich Bonhoeffer

(1906--79) What German-born British biochemist isolated and purified penicillin with Howard Florey, sharing the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine (1945) with Florey and Alexander Fleming?
Sir Ernst Boris Chain

(1906--82) What Soviet statesman's administration was marked by intensified persecution of dissidents at home and by attempted detente followed by renewed Cold War in 1968 and was largely responsible for the invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968?
Leonid Brezhnev

(1906--94) What American teacher, critic, and leading proponent of the New Criticism movement edited The Southern Review from 1935 to 1942, taught at Yale University from 1947 to 1975, and wrote works including Modern poetry and tradition (1939) and The well-wrought urn (1947)?
Cleanth Brooks

(1907--94) What American jazz singer and bandleader was known for his style of scat singing and his flamboyant appearance, is associated with songs such as ``Minnie the moocher'' (1931) and ``Jumpin' jive'' (1939), and led a succession of outstanding big bands from 1928 to 1953?
Cab Calloway

(1908--2009) What French social anthropologist regarded language as an essential common denominator underlying cultural phenomena?
Claude Lévi-Strauss

(1908--2012) What American composer was noted for his innovative approach to meter and his choice of sources as diverse as modern jazz and Renaissance madrigals?
Elliott Carter

(1909--90) What American architect is best known for his use of the International style in corporate architecture, having designed the Lever House in 1952 in New York City and the Hirshhorn Museum and Sculpture Garden in 1974 in Washington, DC?
Gordon Bunshaft

(1909--2000) What Danish-born American pianist was noted for his clowning while playing classical music and his one-man show, Comedy in Music, which began an eight hundred and forty-nine-performance run on Broadway in 1953?
Victor Borge

(1910--95) What Indian-born American astronomer suggested that some stars could eventually collapse to form a dense white dwarf, provided that their mass does not exceed an upper limit (named after him)?
Subrahmanyan Chandrasekhar

(1910--97) What French oceanographer and documentary movie director devised the scuba apparatus but is known primarily for several documentaries and television series on marine life?
Jacques Cousteau

(1910--99) What American writer and composer studied music in Paris and worked as a music critic and composer in the 1930s and later wrote novels, like The sheltering sky (1949), Let it come down (1952), and The spider's house (1966), that typically concerned Westerners in the Arab world?
Paul Bowles

(1911--97) What American biochemist who won the Nobel Prize for Chemistry in 1961 investigated photosynthesis and discovered the cycle of reactions that constitutes the dark reaction?
Melvin Calvin

(1912--77) What German-born American rocket engineer led the development of the V-2 rockets used by Germany in World War II and subsequently moved to the United States where he worked in the Unites States space program?
Wernher von Braun

(1912--92) What American composer, pianist, and writer was noted for his experimental approach, which included the use of aleatory music, periods of silence, and various musical instruments?
John Cage

(1913--76) What English composer, pianist, and conductor composed operas such as Peter Grimes (1945), A midsummer night's dream (1960), and Death in Venice (1973)?
Benjamin Britten

(1913-92) What German statesman and Chancellor of West Germany (1969--74) achieved international recognition for his policy of detente and the opening of relations with the Eastern bloc countries (Ostpolitik) and won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1971?
Willy Brandt

(1914--2009) What American agronomist worked for many years on the improvement of wheat crops and the adaptation of new strains of wheat to parts of the world where it had not previously been grown, winning the Nobel Peace Prize for his work in 1970?
Norman Borlaug

(1916--2001) What American engineer and pioneer of mathematical communication theory investigated digital circuits and was the first to use the term ``bit'' to describe a unit of information?
Claude Elwood Shannon

(1917--2000) What American poet and writer was the first African American woman named as poetry consultant to the Library of Congress (1985--86) and the first to be awarded a Pulitzer Prize for her poetry collected in Annie Allen (1949)?
Gwendolyn Brooks

(1917--2013) What British-born Belgian biochemist was a pioneer in the study of cell biology, winning won the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine in 1974 with Albert Claude (1899--1983) and George Palade (1912--2008)?
Christian René de Duve

(1918--89) What Romanian communist statesman, the first president of the Socialist Republic of Romania (1974--89) and whose regime became increasingly totalitarian and corrupt, was subject to a popular uprising in December 1989 resulted in his regime's downfall and his execution?
Nicolae Ceauşescu

(1920--2006) What American physicist investigated subatomic particles and in 1955 discovered the antiproton with E. G. Segrè (1905--89) and shared the Nobel Prize for Physics (1959) with him?
Owen Chamberlain

(1920--2012) What American jazz pianist, composer, and bandleader formed a quartet in his name in 1951 and gained a reputation as an experimental musician, winning international recognition with the album Time out (1959), which included ``Take five''?
Dave Brubeck

(1920--2012) What American science fiction writer wrote works like The martian chronicles (1950), Fahrenheit 451 (1951), and the semi-autobiographical Green town trilogy: Dandelion wine (1957), Something wicked this way comes (1962), and Farewell summer (2006)?
Ray Bradbury

(1923--77) What American-born operatic soprano of Greek parentage was a coloratura soprano whose bel canto style of singing was especially suited to nineteenth-century Italian opera?
Maria Callas

(1924--2004) What American actor and exponent of method acting first attracted in the stage production of A streetcar named desire (1947), starred in the movie version four years later, and is also noted for On the waterfront (1954), The godfather (1972), and Apocalypse now (1979)?
Marlon Brando

(1925--2016) What influential French composer and conductor was the principal conductor of the New York Philharmonic Orchestra from 1971 to 1978 and wrote an article entitled ``Schoenberg est mort''?
Pierre Boulez

(1926--2019) What Argentinian-born American architect's designs incorporate the special characteristics of each project, such as the World Financial Center and its Winter Garden (1980--89) in New York City and Founders Hall (1987--92) in Charlotte, North Carolina? He also designed the Wells Fargo Centre and the Petronas Twin Towers.
Cesar Pelli

(1929--2002) What American writer, theologian, and rabbi wrote novels like The chosen (1967), The book of lights (1981), and I am the clay (1992), as well as nonfiction and plays?
Chaim Potok

(1931--2007) What Russian statesman resigned from the Communist Party after becoming president of the Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic in 1990 and faced opposition to his reforms?
Boris Yeltsin

(1934--96) What American astronomer showed that amino acids could be synthesized in an artificial primordial soup irradiated by ultraviolet light as a model for a possible mechanism of the origin of life on Earth, wrote several popular science books, and co-produced the television series Cosmos (1980)?
Carl Sagan

(1935--2015) This South African's anti-apartheid novel Looking on darkness (1973) became the first novel in Afrikaans to be banned by the South African government. Identify this novelist, short-story writer, and playwright whose notable works include the novel A dry white season (1979) and the memoir A fork in the road (2009).
André Brink

(1936--59) What American rock-and-roll singer, guitarist, and songwriter who died in an airplane crash recorded such hits as ``That'll be the day'' with his band, The Crickets, before going solo in 1958?
Buddy Holly

(1940--96) What Russian-born American poet and 1991 poet laureate wrote both in Russian and English, was most famous for his collection The end of a beautiful era (1977), and won the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1987?
Joseph Brodsky

(Acer negundo) What American maple of damp soils has leaves resembling the ash and green or purplish twigs?
box elder

(b. 1923) What American pilot became the first person to break the sound barrier when he piloted the Bell X-1 rocket research aircraft at high altitude to a level-flight speed of 670 mph in 1947?
Chuck Yeager

(b. 1928) This theoretical linguist is noted for expounding the theory of generative grammar and also theorized that linguistic behaviour is innate, not learned, and that all languages share the same underlying grammatical base. Name this American who wrote Syntactic structures (1957) and Aspects of the theory of syntax (1965).
Noam Chomsky

(b. 1937) What Russian chess player and world champion was defeated by Bobby Fischer in 1972, moved to Paris in 1975, and had a rematch in 1992 against Fischer, which he again lost?
Boris Spassky

(b. 1946) What Spanish opera singer, noted for his work in operas by Verdi and Puccini, was one of the Three Tenors?
José Carreras

(b. 1954) What American tennis player won the women's singles title at seven French Open, six US Open, three Wimbledon, and two Australian Open tournaments from 1974 to 1986?
Chris Evert

(b. 1956) What Swedish tennis player won the men's singles title at six French Open and five consecutive Wimbledon tournaments from 1974 to 1981?
Björn Borg

(c. 347--407, feast day: 27 January) What Doctor of the Church and bishop of Constantinople's attempts to reform the corrupt state of the court, clergy, and people caused him to be banished in 403?
St. John Chrysostom

(c. 1764--93) What English seaman and mutineer, as first mate under Captain Bligh on the HMS Bounty, seized the ship and cast Bligh and others adrift in April 1789, settling on Pitcairn Island in 1790?
Fletcher Christian

(c. 150--c. 215, feast 5 December) What Greek theologian related the ideas of Greek philosophy to the Christian faith?
St. Clement of Alexandria

(c. 325--297 BC) What Indian emperor founded the Mauryan empire and annexed provinces in Afghanistan from Alexander's Greek successors?
Chandragupta Maurya

(c. 688--741) What Frankish ruler of the eastern part of the Frankish kingdom from 715 and the whole kingdom from 719 was the grandfather of Charlemagne and began Carolingian power?
Charles Martel

(c. 1450--1516) What painter, whose highly detailed works are typically crowded with half-human, half-animal creatures and grotesque demons in settings symbolic of sin and folly, is best known for The garden of earthly delights, Table of the seven deadly sins, Death and the miser, and The haywain?
Hieronymus Bosch

(c. 1476--1507) What Italian statesman, cardinal, and general was the illegitimate son of Pope Alexander VI and brother of Lucrezia?
Cesare Borgia

(c. 1494--1534) What Italian painter's devotional and mythological paintings influenced the rococo style of the eighteenth century?
Antonio Allegri da Correggio

(c. 1510--54) What Spanish explorer's expeditions into Arizona and New Mexico from Mexico opened the Southwest to Spanish colonization?
Francisco Vásquez de Coronado

(c. 1734--1820) What American pioneer made trips west from North Carolina into what is now Kentucky, organizing settlements and successfully defending them from attacks carried out by North American Indians, and later moved further west to Missouri, having been granted land there in 1799?
Daniel Boone

(d. 681 BC) What king of Assyria (705--681) and son of Sargon II put down a Jewish rebellion, laying siege to Jerusalem but sparing it from destruction (according to 2 Kings 19.35) in 701, and also rebuilt the city of Nineveh and made it his capital?
Sennacherib

(feast 23 November) What pope (c. 88--c. 97) was probably the third after St. Peter?
St. Clement

compressed charcoal/coal dust

contention

contention

Define ``bedizen.''
dress up or decorate gaudily

Define ``besmirch.''
damage the reputation of (someone or something) in the opinion of others; make (something) dirty or discoloured

Define ``bourgeoisie.''
polysemous French term referring to the capitalist class that owns most of society's wealth and means of production

Define ``captious.''
tending to find fault or raise petty objections

Define ``chasmic.''
(of a space or divide) extremely deep or large

Define ``coetaneous.''
having the same age or date of origin; contemporary

Define ``condign.''
appropriate to the crime or wrongdoing; fitting and deserved

Define ``corpulent.''
(of a person) fat

Define ``credulous.''
having or showing too great a readiness to believe things

Define ``despondent.''
in low spirits from loss of hope or courage

Define ``emblazon.''
conspicuously inscribe or display a design on; depict (a heraldic device) on something; celebrate or extol publicly

Define ``enmity.''
the state or feeling of being actively opposed or hostile to someone or something

Define ``eviscerate.''
disembowel

Define ``exhortation.''
address or communication emphatically urging someone to do something

Define ``extort.''
obtain (something) by force, threats, or other unfair means

Define ``frivolous.''
not having any serious purpose or value

Define ``gainsay.''
deny or contradict (a fact or statement; speak against or oppose (someone)

Define ``garrulous.''
excessively talkative, especially on trivial matters

Define ``inhere.''
exist essentially or permanently in; (law) (of rights, powers, etc.) be vested in a person or group or attached to the ownership of a property

Define ``insidious.''
proceeding in a gradual, subtle way, but with harmful effects

Define ``languish.''
(of a person or other living thing) lose or lack vitality; grow weak or feeble; suffer from being forced to remain in an unpleasant place or situation

Define ``manifest'' as an adjective.
clear or obvious to the eye or mind

Define ``pallid.''
(of a person's face) pale, typically because of poor health; feeble or insipid

Define ``perspicacious.''
having a ready insight into and understanding of things

Define ``presage.''
(of an event) be a sign or warning that (something, typically something bad) will happen; (of a person) predict; a feeling of presentiment or foreboding

Define ``pretence.''
attempt to make something that is not the case appear true

Define ``prudish.''
having or revealing a tendency to be easily shocked by matters relating to sex or nudity; excessively concerned with sexual propriety

Define ``purport.''
appear or claim to be or do something, especially falsely; profess

Define ``reckoning.''
the action or process of calculating or estimating something; a person's view, opinion, or judgment; the avenging or punishing of past mistakes or misdeeds

Define ``seditious.''
inciting or causing people to rebel against the authority of a state or monarch

Define ``slovenly.''
(especially of a person or their appearance) messy and dirty; (especially of a person or action) careless; excessively casual

Define ``snivelling.''
the action of crying and sniffing in a feeble or fretful way

Define ``stalwart.''
loyal, reliable, and hardworking

Define ``surfeit.''
excessive amount of something

Define ``transpicuous.''
transparent; easily understood, lucid

Define ``vehement.''
showing strong feeling; forceful, passionate, or intense

Define ``vexing.''
causing annoyance, frustration, or worry

For what does ``BGH'' stand?
bovine growth hormone: natural hormone in cattle that helps regulate growth and milk production and that may be produced artificially and given to dairy cattle to increase the yield of milk

For what does ``BSE'' stand?
bovine spongiform encephalopathy: usually fatal disease of cattle affecting the central nervous system, causing agitation and staggering; it is thought to be caused by an agent such as a prion or a virino, and its possible connection with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease in humans is still much debated

For what is ``breakbone fever'' another name?
dengue

For what is ``captcha'' an acronym?
Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart

For what is ``cembalo'' another term?
harpsichord

For what is ``cilantro'' another term?
coriander

madrigal

Bouvier (des Flandres)

Identify him.
Cadmus

congius

clepsydra

bontebok

bontebok

What archaic term referred to an appearance of St. Elmo's fire on a mast, rigging, or other structure?
corposant

What architectural adjective denotes something relating to the lavishly ornamented late Spanish baroque style, named after a Spanish architect who worked in this style?
Churrigueresque

What are belles-lettres?
essays, particularly on literary and artistic criticism, written and read primarily for their aesthetic effect

What are bread and circuses?
palliatives offered especially to avert potential discontent

What are dregs?
the remnants of a liquid left in a container, together with any sediment or grounds

What are the four kinds of conic sections?
circle, ellipse, hyperbola, parabola

What are the lyrics of ``O Haupt voll Blut und Wunden'' that were set by Bach?
O Haupt voll Blut und Wunden, / Voll Schmerz und voller Hohn, / O Haupt, zum Spott gebunden / Mit einer Dornenkron; / O Haupt, sonst schön gezieret / Mit höchster Ehr' und Zier, / Jetzt aber höchst schimpfieret: / Gegrüßet sei'st du mir! / Du edles Angesichte, / Davor sonst schrickt und scheut / Das große Weltgewichte, / Wie bist du so bespeit! / Wie bist du so erbleichet! / Wer hat dein Augenlicht, / Dem sonst kein Licht nicht gleichet, / So schändlich zugericht't?

What are the lyrics to Schiller's ``An die Freude''?
O Freunde, nicht diese Töne! / Sondern laßt uns angenehmere / anstimmen und freudenvollere! / Freude, schöner Götterfunken, / Tochter aus Elysium, / Wir betreten feuertrunken, / Himmlische, dein Heiligtum! / Deine Zauber binden wieder, / Was die Mode streng geteilt; / Alle Menschen werden Brüder, / Wo dein sanfter Flügel weilt. / Wem der große / Wurf gelungen, / Eines Freundes Freund zu sein, / Wer ein holdes Weib errungen, / Mische seinen Jubel ein! / Ja, wer auch nur eine Seele / Sein nennt auf dem Erdenrund! / Und wer's nie gekonnt, der stehle / Weinend sich aus diesem Bund. / Freude trinken alle Wesen / An den Brüsten der Natur; / Alle Guten, alle Bösen / Folgen ihrer Rosenspur. / Küsse gab sie uns und Reben, / Einen Freund, geprüft im Tod; / Wollust ward dem Wurm gegeben, / Und der Cherub steht vor Gott! / Froh, wie seine Sonnen fliegen / Durch des Himmels prächt'gen Plan, / Laufet, Brüder, eure Bahn, / Freudig, wie ein Held zum Siegen. / Seid umschlungen, Millionen. / Diesen Kuß der ganzen Welt! / Brüder! Über'm Sternenzelt / Muß ein lieber Vater wohnen. / Ihr stürzt nieder, Millionen? / Ahnest du den Schöpfer, Welt? / Such' ihn über'm Sternenzelt! / Über Sternen muß er wohnen.

What are the official languages of Burundi?
French, Kirundi

What are the spaces between pieces of flat scenery on a stage or in a theatre called?
coulisses

What are the three principal people groups of Botswana?
Tswana, Kalanga, San (Bushman)

What are the two Chatham Islands of New Zealand?
Pitt, Chatham

What are the two main island groups of the British Antarctic Territory?
South Shetland Islands, South Orkney Islands

What are the two official languages of Comoros?
Arabic, French

What are the words to Hamlet's best-known soliloquy?
To be, or not to be, that is the question: / Whether `tis nobler in the mind to suffer / The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune, / Or to take arms against a sea of troubles / And by opposing end them. To die—to sleep, / No more; and by a sleep to say we end / The heart-ache and the thousand natural shocks / That flesh is heir to: `tis a consummation / Devoutly to be wish'd. To die, to sleep; / To sleep, perchance to dream—ay, there's the rub: / For in that sleep of death what dreams may come, / When we have shuffled off this mortal coil, / Must give us pause—there's the respect / That makes calamity of so long life. / For who would bear the whips and scorns of time, / Th'oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely, / The pangs of dispriz'd love, the law's delay, / The insolence of office, and the spurns / That patient merit of th'unworthy takes, / When he himself might his quietus make / With a bare bodkin? Who would fardels bear, / To grunt and sweat under a weary life, / But that the dread of something after death, / The undiscovere'd country, from whose bourn / No traveller returns, puzzles the will, / And makes us rather bear those ills we have / Than fly to others that we know not of? / Thus conscience doth make cowards of us all, / And thus the native hue of resolution / Is sicklied o'er with the pale cast of thought, / And enterprises of great pith and moment / With this regard their currents turn awry / And lose the name of action.

What assertion states that there is no set whose cardinality is strictly between that of the integers and the real numbers?
continuum hypothesis

What asymmetrical arrangement of the human figure has the line of the arms and shoulders contrasting with, while balancing, those of the hips and legs?
contrapposto

What austere contemplative order was founded by St. Bruno in 1084?
Carthusians

What Australian tennis player won more Grand Slam events than any other player (sixty-two)?
Margaret Smith Court

What autonomous region of central Spain has its capital in Toledo?
Castilla--La Mancha

What autonomous region of northern Spain has its capital in Valladolid?
Castilla-León

What bacterial disease typically affecting cattle and buffalo and causes undulant fever in humans?
brucellosis

What band of tissue on the lowest part of a horse's pastern contains the horn-producing cells from which the hoof grows?
coronet

What basic monetary unit of Cameroon, Congo, Gabon, and the Central African Republic is equal to 100 centimes?
CFA franc

What basic monetary unit of Ghana is equal to 100 pesewas?
cedi

What bed of shale exposed in the Rocky Mountains in British Columbia, Canada, dated to the Cambrian period (about 530 million years ago), is rich in well-preserved fossils of early marine invertebrates, many of which represent evolutionary lineages unknown in later times?
Burgess Shale

What beet is of a variety with broad white leaf stalks that may be prepared and eaten separately from the green parts of the leaf?
chard

What bicyclic compound with fused benzene and furan rings, with the chemical formula C8H6O, is present in coal tar and used to make thermoplastic resins for paints and varnishes?
coumarone

What billiards stroke involves the cue ball striking two balls successively?
carom

What biological term refers to the coalescence or growing together of parts originally separate?
concrescence

What bird family comprises the crows?
Corvidae

What black China tea comes from the last crop of the season and is usually considered low quality?
bohea

bohea

choler

cladode

chronostratigraphy

Ceará

Charolais

Border Leicester

What British cavalry charge in 1854 of the Battle of Balaclava in the Crimean War involved a fatal misunderstanding and was immortalized in verse by Tennyson?
Charge of the Light Brigade

What British racing cyclist born in 1980 holds the record for the most Olympic medals won by a British athlete (eight) and was the first British winner of the Tour de France in 2012?
Sir Bradley Wiggins

What British term historically referred to the right to fish in water belonging to someone else?
common of piscary

What brittle reddish-brown crystalline mineral with an iridescent purple tarnish and consisting of a sulphide of copper and iron was named after a prominent eighteenth-century Austrian mineralogist?
bornite

What broad band of nerve fibres joins the two hemispheres of the brain?
corpus callosum

What broad border is used as a charge in a coat of arms, often as a mark of difference?
bordure

What burrowing wormlike amphibian of a tropical order is distinguished by poorly developed eyes and the lack of limbs?
caecilian

Sir Mackenzie Bowell

Burkitt's lymphoma

Cape Trafalgar

What cape is the site of the John F. Kennedy Space Center?
Cape Canaveral

What capsule-shaped membranous structure surrounding the glomerulus of each nephron in the kidneys of mammals extracts wastes, excess salts, and water from the blood?
Bowman's capsule

What celestial object, intermediate in size between a giant planet and a small star, is believed to emit mainly infrared radiation?
brown dwarf

What character in Italian commedia dell'arte is the mistress of Harlequin?
Columbine

What chief port of Romania was formerly called ``Tomis'' and renamed for a Roman emperor?
Constanţa

Candlemas

uroboros

What city in the state of North Rhine-Westphalia in Germany was the capital of the Federal Republic of Germany from 1949 to 1990?
Bonn

Bonn

Chondrichthyes

Chilopoda

Cestoda

cerebrospinal fluid

Clarence

What cloud forming a broken layer of small fleecy clouds at high altitude, usually 16,500--45,000 feet (5--13 km), typically has a rippled or granulated appearance (as in a mackerel sky)?
cirrocumulus

What cloud forms a thin, more or less uniform, semitranslucent layer at high altitude, usually 16,500--45,000 feet (5--13 km)?
cirrostratus

What cloud forms wispy filamentous tufted streaks (``mare's tails'') at high altitude, usually 16,500--45,000 feet (5--13 km)?
cirrus

bushido

What coenzyme derived from pantothenic acid is important in respiration and many other biochemical reactions?
coenzyme A

cloaca

Johannes Brahms

narcolepsy

Cancer

contrecoup

Claude glass

maleic acid/cis-butenedioic acid

arabonic acid

couvade

cAMP (cyclic adenosine monophosphate)

What cyclical pattern of breathing involves movement gradually decreasing to a complete stop and then returning to normal, occurring in various medical conditions and at high altitudes?
Cheyne--Stokes breathing

chlorambucil

Charybdis

Bornholm

Coalsack

Cassandra

calutron

chymotrypsin

Chagas's disease

Buerger's disease

celiac disease

Bright's disease

What effect involves a mass moving in a rotating system experiencing a force acting perpendicular to the direction of motion and to the axis of rotation?
Coriolis effect

ma'at

Aquifoliaceae

What Fate's name comes from the Greek for ``she who spins''?
Clotho

What female reproductive organ of a flower consists of an ovary, a stigma, and usually a style?
carpel

chernozem

chitin

Cepheus

What first secretion from the mammary glands after giving birth is rich in antibodies?
colostrum

transom

What fluid-filled canal runs through the midbrain connecting the third and fourth ventricles?
cerebral aqueduct

What folk religion practiced in South America (especially Brazil) is based on traditional African religious practices modified by elements of Roman Catholicism and spiritualism?
candomblé

What followers of a strictly orthodox Jewish sect in Palestine in the third and second centuries BC opposed Hellenizing influences on their faith and supported the Maccabean revolt?
Hasidim

Natufian culture

What form of carbon has molecules of sixty atoms arranged in a polyhedron resembling a geodesic sphere?
buckminsterfullerene

What form of necrosis characteristic of tuberculosis involves diseased tissue forming a firm, dry mass like cheese in appearance?
caseation

What form of the mineral andalusite contains carbonaceous inclusions that cause some sections of the mineral to show the figure of a cross?
chiastolite

What formal term for a conversation more commonly refers to a gathering for discussion of theological questions?
colloquy

What formal term from the Greek for ``to praise'' refers to a person who publicly praises or flatters someone else?
encomiast

What formal term is ascribed to a selection of passages from an author or authors designed to help in learning a language?
chrestomathy

What formal term means to prove a person or an assertion to be wrong?
confute

What formal term means to walk all the way around something?
circumambulate

What formal term, from the Latin for ``dinner,'' is given to a group of people, such as a discussion group or literary clique?
cenacle

What formal verb means to think deeply about something, meditate, or reflect?
cogitate

What formal word from the Latin ``through'' + ``speak'' means ``speak at length''?
perorate

What formal word from the Latin for ``restrain, answer conclusively'' means to prove a person or an assertion wrong?
confute

What former duchy and province in central France has its chief town in Moulins?
Bourbonnais

What former homeland was established in South Africa for the Tswana people?
Bophuthatswana

What fourth ecumenical council of the Christian Church, held in 451, condemned the Monophysite position and affirmed the dual but united nature of Christ as god and man?
Council of Chalcedon

What fourth of eight standard parrying positions in fencing has the blade up and to the inside, wrist supinated?
quarte

What fowl's name is used for a batsman's dismissal with a score of zero in cricket?
duck

Colles fracture

What French adjective means ``served with a sauce of red wine and onions''?
bordelaise

choucroute garni

What French game is a form of lawn bowling on rough ground and using a metal ball?
boules

What French name is given to a long Turkish tobacco pipe?
chibouk

What French national theatre used for both comedy and tragedy in Paris was founded in 1680 by Louis XIV?
Comédie-Française

What French poet's courtly romances on Arthurian themes include Lancelot (c. 1177--81) and Perceval (c. 1181--90, unfinished)?
Chrétien de Troyes

What French term for a formal report or review shares its name with a document published in February 1781 by Jacques Necker?
compte rendu

What French term meaning ``stroke of eye'' refers to a glance that takes in a comprehensive view?
coup d'œil

What French term meaning ``stroke of lightning'' refers to a sudden unforeseen event, in particular an instance of love at first sight?
coup de foudre

What French term of footwear is used to change the subject?
à propos de bottes

What French term refers to a final blow or shot given to kill a wounded person or animal?
coup de grâce

What French type of blood sausage shares its name with a spicy sausage used especially in Louisiana cuisine?
boudin

What French word meaning ``running'' refers to a sixteenth-century court dance consisting of short advances and retreats?
courante

What French word refers to a fabric with an irregularly raised or embossed surface?
cloqué

What French word that denoted a bundle of papers with a label on the back now means a collection of documents about a particular person, event, or subject?
dossier

What French-derived term refers to a group of sycophantic followers or people hired to applaud (or heckle) a performer or public speaker?
claque

What French-derived term refers to a small stream or a lava flow?
coulee

What French-derived word is given to an enlarged part of a nerve fibre or cell, especially an axon, where it forms a synapse with another nerve?
bouton

What fungicide for vines, fruit trees, and other plants is composed of equal quantities of copper sulphate and calcium oxide in water and named after a region in France?
Bordeaux mixture

What genus of Asian trees (family Thymelaeaceae) has lanceolate leaves and nearly sessile umbels of flowers?
Aquilaria

What geographical term, which is also a name for Qaanaaq and a word for the culture existing in the arctic lands from Alaska to Greenland from about 500 to 1400, was a country described by Pytheas as being six days' sail north of Britain, most plausibly identified with Norway, and regarded by the ancients as the northernmost part of the world?
Thule

What geologic formation or stratum confines water in an adjacent aquifer?
aquiclude

What geologic formation or stratum that lies adjacent to an aquifer allows only a small amount of liquid to pass?
aquitard

What German Nazi politician, whose skeleton, exhumed in Berlin, was identified in 1973 after disappearing at the end of World War II, was considered Hitler's closest collaborator?
Martin Bormann

What German state surrounds Berlin?
Brandenburg

(feast day: 6 October) What German-born French churchman and saint founded the Carthusian order at La Grande Chartreuse in 1084?
St. Bruno

What Germanized word is given to brass, tortoiseshell, or another material that is cut to make a pattern and used for inlaying furniture?
buhl

What glandular sac opening into the cloaca of a bird produces B cells?
bursa of Fabricius

What gliding step in dancing involves one foot displacing the other?
chassé

What glycosaminoglycan and constituent of cartilage and other connective tissue occurs mainly in the form of sulphate esters?
chondroitin

What gnostic term refers to the spiritual universe as the abode of God and the totality of the divine powers and emanations?
pleroma

What Gram-positive, anaerobic, toxin-producing bacterium can infect the bowel, causing illness with diarrhea and fever, especially in people who have been treated with antibiotics?
Clostridium difficile

What grammatical term denotes a word or phrase that refers to or stands for a later word or phrase?
cataphora

What Greek and Roman Muse of epic poetry shares its name with a keyboard instrument resembling an organ but with the notes produced by steam whistles, used chiefly on showboats and in travelling fairs?
Calliope

What Greek architect was the leading architect in Periclean Athens and designed the Parthenon with Ictinus (447--38 BC)?
Callicrates

What Greek mythological figure was a fire-breathing female monster with a lion's head, a goat's body, and a serpent's tail, and shares its name with an organism containing a mixture of genetically different tissues, formed by processes such as fusion of early embryos, grafting, or mutation?
Chimera

What Greek phrase meaning ``mystical marriage'' refers to a sacred marriage that plays out between a god and a goddess, especially when enacted in a symbolic ritual where human participants represent the deities?
hieros gamos

What Greek poet and scholar wrote hymns and epigrams and was head of the library at Alexandria?
Callimachus

What gregarious piglike mammal is found from the south-western United States to Paraguay?
peccary

What group of fifteen islands in the southwestern Pacific Ocean between Tonga and French Polynesia has the status of a self-governing territory in free association with New Zealand and has its capital in Avarua?
Cook Islands

What group of islands in the western Pacific Ocean, north of the equator, is divided between the Federated States of Micronesia and Palau?
Caroline Islands

What group of mountains near the Mediterranean coast in northwestern Israel, sheltering the port of Haifa, was the scene of the defeat of the priests of Baal by the prophet Elijah (1 Kings 18)?
Mount Carmel

What group of seven small islands in the western Philippines is located in the Sulu Sea?
Cagayan Islands

What group of small bones between the main part of the forelimb and the metacarpus in terrestrial vertebrates forms the wrist in humans?
carpus

What gulf in the Canadian Arctic Ocean in the Northwest Territories is located between a peninsula of the same name and Baffin Island?
Gulf of Boothia

What hardness test involves hydraulically pressing a steel ball into the metal and measuring the resulting indentation?
Brinell hardness test

compony

What heraldic name is given to an ordinary in the form of a broad inverted V-shape?
chevron

canting arms

canton

What heraldic term refers to a stag, bull, or other figure shown full face with no neck?
caboshed

What heraldic term refers to the status of a younger branch of a family?
cadency

What heraldic verb means to interchange the tinctures of a charge with that of a divided field?
counterchange

What hill in the Charlestown section of northern Boston in Massachusetts gave its name to the first pitched battle (1775) of the American Revolution, which was actually fought on nearby Breed's Hill, and considerable impetus to the Revolution despite the British victory?
Bunker Hill

What Hindu-postulated cycle comprises 12,000 years, ending with a dissolution (a pralaya) which is repeated more drastically at the end of the thousandth cycle, and repeats 360 times to form one cosmic period of 4,320,000 years?
mahayuga

What historic commune that existed in the 1840s in West Roxbury and is now a southwestern section of Boston in Massachusetts was associated with Margaret Fuller and other writers?
Brook Farm

What historic port city in northern Haiti was the country's former capital of Haiti and is the second-largest city in the country?
Cap-Haïtien

What historic stream in southeastern Pennsylvania and northern Delaware is the birthplace of the American gunpowder industry?
Brandywine Creek

What historical or humourous term of French origin refers to a woman's bedroom or private room?
boudoir

What holy city of Islam in Tunisia was founded by the Umayyads around 670 and is the site of the Mosque of Uqba?
Kairouan

What hormone abbreviated ``CCK'' secreted by duodenal cells stimulates the release of bile into the intestine and the secretion of enzymes by the pancreas?
cholecystokinin

What hormone that cells in the duodenum secrete stimulates the release of bile into the intestine and the secretion of enzymes by the pancreas?
cholecystokinin

What hormone released in the blood in some circumstances causes smooth muscle contraction and blood vessel dilation and is a peptide comprising nine amino-acid residues?
bradykinin

What hormone secreted during pregnancy by the placenta stimulates the continued production of progesterone by the ovaries?
chorionic gonadotropin

What hormone-secreting structure develops after an ovum has been discharged but degenerates after a few days unless pregnancy has begun?
corpus luteum

What huge bronze statue of the sun god Helios was built circa 292--280 BC?
Colossus of Rhodes

Borscht Belt

Bonneville Dam

Bonneville Dam

Book of Kells

Book of Kells

Boricua

clinometer

branks

Congress of Vienna

What is a syllogism?
instance of a form of reasoning in which a conclusion is drawn (whether validly or not) from two given or assumed propositions (premises), each of which shares a term with the conclusion and shares a common or middle term not present in the conclusion (e.g., all dogs are animals; all animals have four legs; therefore all dogs have four legs)

Ferruccio Busoni

bresaola

carpaccio

braciola

cholent

Gehenna (Jer. 19.5--6)

Logos

classifying adjective

What kind of alcohol is Cinzano?
vermouth

What kind of compound has molecules of one component physically trapped within the crystal structure of another?
clathrate

clastic rocks

conidium

clafoutis

capital gains tax

Cambyses

bulgogi

Lake Champlain

Lake Constance

Lake Como

What lake on the Zambezi River in western Mozambique has its waters impounded by a dam and massive hydroelectric complex?
Cabora Bassa

What large bone forming the heel articulates with the cuboid bone of the foot and the talus bone of the ankle and is attached to the Achilles tendon?
calcaneus

Camelopardalis

Copepoda

Chelicerata

cymbalom

Cetus

chador

What large southern constellation lies in the Milky Way and contains the stars Alpha Centauri and Proxima Centauri?
Centaurus

Doyenne du Comice

coelacanth

What largely rural county in east-central California in the Sierra Nevada is associated with the 1840s gold rush and the writings of Mark Twain?
Calaveras County

Broederbond

What Latin adverb translates as ``against the world''?
contra mundum

What Latin adverbial phrase means ``with other conditions remaining the same''?
ceteris paribus

corpus delicti

What Latin name is given to an existing melody used as the basis for a polyphonic composition?
cantus firmus

What Latin phrase refers to the principle that the buyer alone is responsible for checking the quality and suitability of goods before a purchase is made?
caveat emptor

What Latin phrase which appears in Hamlet (1.5.159) means ``here and everywhere''?
hic et ubique

What Latin poet of the late Roman Republic wrote chiefly in the neoteric style of poetry is known for his love poems?
Gaius Valerius Catullus

bona fide

bona fide

Charles's law

Chiron

chametz

Lucius Junius Brutus

referent

conductus

cladistics

What noun, whose name originates from the Latin for ``small,'' refers to any of a class of very small viruses chiefly affecting animals, especially one which causes contagious disease in dogs?
parvovirus

What nuclear reactor of a Canadian design has unenriched uranium oxide clad in zircaloy as fuel and heavy water as a coolant and moderator?
CANDU

What nymph of Greek mythos was changed into a bear by Zeus?
Callisto

What ocean passage between Newfoundland and Nova Scotia links the Gulf of St. Lawrence with the Atlantic Ocean?
Cabot Strait

What officer rank in the British army is above colonel and below major general?
brigadier

What offset printing method utilizes a gelatin-coated zinc plate hardened and sensitized to print type, line illustrations, and fine-screen halftones?
aquatone

What old man ferried the souls of the dead across the Styx and Acheron Rivers to Hades?
Charon

What one-syllable word means (of words or the person speaking them) fluent and voluble but insincere and shallow?
glib

What open carriage with a Polish name had a calash top and space for reclining?
britzka

What order of insects comprises the beetles (including weevils) and forms the largest order of animals on the earth?
Coleoptera

What order of insects comprises the springtails?
Collembola

What order of mammals comprises the bats?
Chiroptera

What order of marine mammals, comprising the whales, dolphins, and porpoises, have a streamlined hairless body, no hind limbs, a horizontal tail fin, and a blowhole on top of the head for breathing?
Cetacea

What order of minute branchiopod crustaceans includes the water fleas, typically having a transparent shell enclosing the trunk and large antennae used for swimming?
Cladocera

What organ stop has the quality of a flute?
clarabella

What organelle near the nucleus of a cell contains the centrioles (in animal cells) and begets the spindle fibres in cell division?
centrosome

What osteoarthritis of the hock in horses sometimes causes swelling and lameness?
bone spavin

bone spavin

What outermost membrane surrounding an embryo of a reptile, bird, or mammal contributes to the formation of the placenta in mammals?
chorion

What painful condition of the hand and fingers caused by compression of a major nerve may be caused by repetitive movements over a long period or by fluid retention and is characterized by sensations of tingling, numbness, or burning?
carpal tunnel syndrome

What pair of granite obelisks erected at Heliopolis by Tuthmosis III was taken from Egypt in 1878, one being set up on the Thames Embankment in London and the other in Central Park, New York?
Cleopatra's Needles

What papal verb means to ``express one's opinions in a way considered annoyingly pompous and dogmatic''?
pontificate

What part of the basal ganglia of the brain comprises the caudate and lentiform nuclei?
corpus striatum

What part of the eye connects the iris to the choroid?
ciliary body

What part of the Pacific Ocean is at the centre of the Molucca Islands?
Ceram Sea

What patterns are formed when a sand-covered surface is made to vibrate, the sand collecting in the regions of least motion?
Chladni figures

What peak on Mount Desert Island in southeastern Maine, within Acadia National Park, is the highest point on the east coast of the United States?
Cadillac Mountain

What peninsula in eastern North Carolina is often called ``the Graveyard of the Atlantic'' because of the treacherous waters around?
Cape Hatteras

What pentasyllabic adjective means ``surrounding,'' usually in a literary or formal setting?
circumambient

What people of northern Iran held political supremacy through the dynasty ruling Persia from 1794 to 1925?
Kajar

What people of southern Russia and Ukraine are noted for their horsemanship and military skill?
Cossacks

What perforated bowl is used to strain off liquid from food, especially after cooking?
colander

What period of Lower Palaeolithic culture of Europe dates to about 250,000--200,000 years ago?
Clactonian

What personality disorder is characterized by severe mood swings, impulsive behaviour, and difficulty forming stable personal relationships?
borderline personality disorder

What personification of Britain is usually depicted as a helmeted woman with a shield and trident?
Britannia

What philosophical and psychological term refers to volition---the mental faculty of purpose, desire, or will to perform an action?
conation

What philosophical concept is concerned with the art of investigating or discussing the truth of opinions or the inquiry into metaphysical contradictions and their solutions?
dialectics

What philosophical principle establishes the existence of a being from the fact of its thinking or awareness?
cogito

What phonetic adjective describes something pronounced with the tip of the tongue curled up toward the hard palate?
retroflex/cacuminal

What phonetic term refers to pronouncing two or more speech sounds together so that one influences the other?
coarticulation

What phrase from Shakespeare's Macbeth (1.4.7) was popularized by Sir Walter Scott and referred to a favourable position for observation or action?
coign of vantage

Brachiopoda

Bryozoa

Chlorophyta

What physical object generalizes the notion of a point particle to higher dimensions?
brane

What physiological adjective refers to a biological process recurring naturally on a twenty-four-hour cycle, even in the absence of light fluctuations?
circadian

What plane quartic curve associated with Nicomedes consists of two separate branches on either side of and asymptotic to a central straight line (the asymptote), such that if a line is drawn from a fixed point (the pole) to intersect both branches, the part of the line falling between the two branches is of constant length and is exactly bisected by the asymptote?
conchoid

What plant of the buttercup family, bearing showy flowers with backward-pointing spurs, native to temperate regions of the northern hemisphere, and widely grown in gardens, is associated with columbines?
aquilegia

mandorla

Vistula

Concordia

Annaba/Bône

Annaba/Bône

cheval-de-frise

collotype

corbel

calmodulin

brandade

Boz

catatonia

charas

cognitive dissonance

gestalt

chyme

QCD

clitellum

Cheviot Hills

Cascade Range

corporeity

chirm

claret

What term, Hebrew for ``priest,'' refers to a member of the priestly class having certain rights and duties in the synagogue?

concordance

What term, referring to a historical shrill narrow-tubed war trumpet, means in modern English a strongly expressed demand or request for action?

catabolism

complement fixation test

What test made in early pregnancy to detect congenital abnormalities in the fetus involves taking a tiny tissue sample from the threadlike projections of the fetal part of the placenta?
chorionic villus sampling

What theological doctrine posits that the body and blood of Christ are present in the bread and wine of the Eucharist?
concomitance

Logos

What theology refers to knowledge of God obtained through affirmation?
cataphatic

What therapy for mercury or lead poisoning binds the toxins in the bloodstream by circulating a certain solution?
chelation therapy

cothurnus

What thin layer of gray matter in each cerebral hemisphere is located between the lentiform nucleus and the insula?
claustrum

cannula

cortina

execrable

trabea

conchiolin

What town in northwestern Italy, in Tuscany, is known for the white marble quarried there since Roman times?
Carrara

Breda

What town is home to the University of North Carolina?
Chapel Hill

cantharidin

cadaverine

What trademarked term for a man's wide-brimmed hat comes from the Italian fashion house founded in 1857 that manufactured it?

celluloid

What transparent fluid occupies the space between the crystalline lens and the cornea of the eye?
aqueous humour

What tribe or suborder of crustaceans is characterized by short abdomens folded toward the ventral surface and includes the true crabs?
brachyura

What tributary of the Vistula in northeastern Poland flows west and southwest into the Bug River?
Narew

What tropical marine mollusk with a spiral shell that may bear long projections and have a flared lip shares its name with the roof of a semicircular apse, shaped like half a dome?
conch

What Turkish city was the capital of the Ottoman Empire from 1326 to 1402?
Bursa

What twining plant with trumpet-shaped flowers may be either an invasive weed or cultivated for its bright flowers, like morning glories?
convolvulus

What type of aria is characterized by a declamatory melodic style?
aria parlante

krummhorn

crura cerebri (singular crus cerebri)

What branch of biology deals with the properties of organisms and tissues at low temperatures?

What protein that occurs in the blood in certain disorders can be precipitated out of solution below ten degrees Celsius, causing obstruction in the fingers and toes?
cryoglobulin

What underground room or vault beneath a church is used as a chapel or burial place?
crypt

What dated botanical term referred to a plant that had no true flowers or seeds, including ferns, mosses, liverworts, lichens, algae, and fungi?
cryptogam

In what condition does one or both of the testes fail to descend from the abdomen into the scrotum?
cryptorchidism

In what period did rocks contain no, or only slight, traces of living organisms?
Precambrian

Crystal Palace

What Hungarian dance has a slow introduction and a fast, wild finish?
csardas

ctenidium

Ctenophora

cuadrilla

Cuba libre

elbow

cubitus

$q^{-1} + 744 + 196884q + 21493760q^2 + 864299970q^3 + 20245856256q^4$

Cúcuta

Cucurbitaceae

cue bid

Cuenca

Cuernavaca

cuesta

What early angular form of the Arabic alphabet is found chiefly in decorative inscriptions?
Kufic

What Latin exclamation translates to ``to whom is it a benefit?'' usually referring to a crime?
cui bono?

cuirass

cuirass

What was a piece of armour for the thigh called?
cuisse

Ely Culbertson

cultch

Culdees

Culex

What city in north-western Mexico is the capital of Sinaloa?
Culiacán Rosales

What series of Carboniferous strata in southwestern England is mainly shale and limestone with some thin coal seams?
Culm

What name is shared between the upper ridge of a bird's bill and a small region in the brain on the anterior surface of the cerebellum?
culmen

Gorgon

Who are the three Gorgons?
Euryale, Medusa, Stheno

Coatlicue
