What word that primarily refers to an organ stop sounding a main register of flue pipes of eight-foot pitch can, in the literary sense, refer to the entire compass, range, or scope of something?
diapason

What name is given to a period of suspended development in an insect, another invertebrate, or mammal embryo, especially during unfavourable environmental conditions?
diapause

What name is given to the passage of blood cells through the intact walls of the capillaries, typically accompanying inflammation?
diapedesis

What low-pitched fog signal operated by compressed air is characterized by the ``grunt'' that ends each note?
diaphone

What enzyme of the flavoprotein type can oxidize a reduced form of NAD?
diaphorase

What is the technical term for sweating?
diaphoresis

What name is given to the shaft or central part of a long bone?
diaphysis

What is an interloper?
one that intrudes in a place or sphere of activity

In what domed rock formation has a rock core moved upward to pierce the overlying strata?
diapir

(c. 1450--1500) What Portuguese navigator and explorer was the first European to sail around the Cape of Good Hope (1488), thereby establishing a sea route from the Atlantic Ocean to Asia?
Bartolomeu Dias

What separation of the muscles along the midline of the abdomen is typical during and after pregnancy and in newborns?
diastasis recti

What name is given to a space separating teeth of different functions, especially between the biting teeth (incisors and canines) and grinding teeth (premolars and molars) in rodents and ungulates?
diastema

What is the phase of the heartbeat when the heart muscle relaxes and allows the chambers to fill with blood called?
diastole

What name is given to the four Gospels combined into a single narrative?
diatessaron

Identify the planktonic single-celled alga with a cell wall of silica of which extensive fossil deposits have been found.
diatom

What tranquillizing muscle-relaxant drug of the benzodiazepine group is used chiefly to relieve anxiety, is also called ``Valium,'' and has the chemical formula C16H13N2OCl?
diazepam

What name is given to an organic compound containing two nitrogen atoms bonded together?
diazo

What psychoanalytic procedure allows the untrammelled expression of the conscious mind to help gain insight into the unconscious?
free association

What is recourse?
turning to someone or something for help or protection

What is inculcation?
teaching and impressing by frequent repetitions or admonitions

(c. 1548--1620) What Flemish mathematician, physicist, and engineer has his proof of the equilibrium on an inclined plane on his epitaph, discovered the hydrostatic paradox, was the first to explain the tides by the attraction of the moon, was the first to relate twelve-tone equal temperament and the twelfth-root of two, was responsible for many Dutch neologisms, invented the Zeilwagen `land yacht,' and tripled the efficiency of the windmills used in pumping water out of the polders?
Simon Stevin

What poisonous, reactive gas made by the action of acids is an example of electron-deficient bonding and has the chemical formula B2H6?
diborane

To what genus do the bleeding hearts belong?
Dicentra

What name is given to a cyme in which each flowering branch gives rise to two or more branches symmetrically placed?
dichasium

What pale yellow liquid used as an insecticide and veterinary anthelmintic has the chemical formula (CH3O)2PO2CHCCl2?
dichlorvos

What is the ripening of the stamens and pistils of a flower at different times so that self-fertilization is prevented called?
dichogamy

(1706--39) What English robber was a cattle and deer thief in Essex before becoming a partner with Tom King, a notorious highway robber who was hanged for horse-stealing?
Dick Turpin

In what year was Charles Dickens born?
1812

In what year did Charles Dickens die?
1870

What medal is awarded to an animal in recognition of an act of great bravery, typically one performed during a time of military conflict by an animal attached to the armed forces?
Dickin medal

For what is ``dictamnus'' another term?
dittany of Crete

What order of insects comprises the cockroaches and mantises with a somewhat flattened form, two pairs of wings, and long spiky legs?
Dictyoptera

What drug inhibiting the replication of HIV is used in the treatment of AIDS, especially in combination with zidovudine and a synthetic analogue of a pyrimidine nucleoside?
dideoxycytidine

What queen and founder of Carthage fell in love with the shipwrecked Aeneas and killed herself when he deserted her?
Dido

What ancient sanctuary of Apollo, the site of one of the most famous oracles of the Aegean region, is close to the west coast of Asia Minor?
Didyma

What plant genus includes the dumb cane?
Dieffenbachia

What is the largest island of the Chagos Archipelago in the middle of the Indian Ocean, the site of a strategic Anglo-American naval base established in 1973?
Diego Garcia

(1886--1957) What Mexican painter inspired a revival of fresco painting in Latin America and the US, created a mural of the history of Mexico for the National Palace in Mexico City, and was married to Frida Kahlo?
Diego Rivera

(1599--1660) What Spanish painter's portraits humanized the formal Spanish tradition of idealized figures? His works include Pope Innocent X (1650), The toilet of Venus (known as The Rokeby Venus, c. 1651), and Las meninas (c. 1656).
Diego Velázquez

(c. 1465--1524) After sailing with Columbus to the New World in 1493, what Spanish conquistador began the conquest of Cuba in 1511 and later initiated expeditions to conquer Mexico?
Diego Velázquez de Cuéllar

What toxic insecticide produced by the oxidation of aldrin, now banned because of its persistence in the environment, has the chemical formula C12H8Cl6O?
dieldrin

What quantity measures the ability of a substance to store electrical energy in an electric field?
dielectric constant/relative permittivity

What name is given to the migration of uncharged particles towards the position of maximum field strength in a non-uniform electric field?
dielectrophoresis

In what addition reaction does a conjugated diene react with a compound with a double or triple bond to form a six-membered ring?
Diels--Alder reaction

What village in northwestern Vietnam was the site of a French military post that the Vietminh captured after a 55-day siege in 1954?
Dien Bien Phu

What name is given to the caudal (posterior) part of the forebrain, containing the epithalamus, thalamus, hypothalamus, ventral thalamus, and third ventricle?
diencephalon

What channel port in northern France, from which ferries run to Newhaven and elsewhere, was the scene of an unsuccessful amphibious raid by a joint force of British and Canadian troops to destroy the German-held port and airfield?
Dieppe

What name is given to a day that does not count for legal purposes?
dies non

What was the first name of the French-German engineer that invented the diesel engine?
Rudolf

What is the double dagger symbol called?
diesis

What 1521 meeting convoked by Holy Roman emperor Charles V did Martin Luther attend to the cause of Protestant reform, his teaching being formally condemned in an edict of a parallel name?
Diet of Worms

What pleasant-smelling, colourless, volatile, and highly flammable liquid has the chemical formula C2H5OC2H5?
diethyl ether

What colourless soluble liquid that is used as a solvent and antifreeze has the chemical formula (C2H4OH)2O?
diethylene glycol

(1901--92) What German-born American actress and singer who became famous as Lola in The blue angel (1930), one of many films she made with Josef von Sternberg, was also successful as an international cabaret star from the 1950s?
Marlene Dietrich

Where did Dietrich Buxtehude work?
Lübeck

(1925--2012) What German baritone is noted for his interpretations of German lieder, particularly Schubert's song cycles?
Dietrich Fischer-Dieskau

What is the motto of the British monarch?
Dieu et mon droit

What Canadian phrase means ``fail to be voted on before the end of a legislative session''?
die on the Order Paper

What word, from the Latin for ``wander,'' refers to an unexpected and inexplicable change in a situation or someone's behaviour?
vagary

Fill in the proverb: ``different [---] for different folks.''
strokes

What name is given to a member of a principal sect of Jainism that was formed as a result of doctrinal schism in about 80 AD and continues today in parts of southern India? Its male ascetic members traditionally reject property ownership and do not wear clothes.
Digambara

What was the sixth letter of the early Greek alphabet, probably pronounced as ``w''?
digamma

What soft-brimmed felt hat is worn as part of the Australian army uniform?
digger's hat

What solitary wasp (families Sphecidae and Pompilidae) typically excavates a burrow in sandy soil, filling it with one or more paralyzed insects or spiders for its larvae to feed on?
digger wasp

What drug is prepared from the dried leaves of foxgloves and contains substances that stimulate the heart muscle?
digitalis

What adjective describes something shaped like a spread hand?
digitate

What situation in which two languages (or two varieties of the same language) are used under different conditions within a community, often by the same speakers, is usually referenced with respect to languages with distinct ``high'' and ``low'' (colloquial) varieties, such as Arabic?
diglossia

What poisonous compound present in the foxglove and other plants is a steroid glycoside and used in small doses as a cardiac stimulant?
digoxin

What name is given to a combination of two letters representing one sound or a ligature?
digraph

What synthetic compound with strong reducing properties is used in lotions for colouring the skin in sunlight and has the chemical formula (CH2OH)CO?
dihydroxyacetone

What is the capital of Burgundy?
Dijon

What German-derived word refers to an order or decree imposed by someone in power without popular consent?
diktat

What phenomenon exhibited by some fluids, sols, and gels involves the substance becoming more viscous or solid under pressure?
dilatancy

What noun, from the Italian for ``person loving the arts,'' refers to someone who cultivates an area of interest without real commitment or knowledge?
dilettante

What earliest of the large bipedal dinosaurs had two long crests on the head and occurred in the early Jurassic period?
dilophosaurus

(1913--65) What English broadcaster was the BBC's first news correspondent (1936) and was particularly noted for his radio and television commentaries on royal, national, and international events?
Richard Dimbleby

What is a molecule or molecular complex consisting of two identical molecules linked together called?
dimer

What colourless, oily liquid with an unpleasant smell is used as an antidote for poisoning by mercury, arsenic, lead, and other heavy metals and has the chemical formula CH2(SH)CH(SH)CH2OH?
dimercaprol

What line of verse consists of two metrical feet?
dimeter

What colourless liquid used as a solvent and synthetic reagent is readily able to penetrate the skin, is used in medicinal preparations for skin application, and has the chemical formula (CH3)2SO?
dimethyl sulphoxide

What large fossil carnivorous mammal-like reptile of the Permian period had long spines on its back supporting a sail-like crest?
dimetrodon

What name is attributed to the combination of two coats of arms by juxtaposing the dexter half of one and the sinister half of the other on a single shield (a practice primarily superseded by impalement)?
dimidiation

What hard-wearing cotton fabric is woven with stripes or checks?
dimity

What does ``DIMM'' abbreviate in computing?
dual in-line memory module

What Chinese dish consists of small steamed or fried savoury dumplings containing various fillings?
dim sum

What basic monetary unit of Serbia is equivalent to 100 paras?
dinar

What basic monetary unit of Jordan, Bahrain, and Iraq is equivalent to 1000 fils?
dinar

What basic monetary unit of Libya is equivalent to 1000 dirhams?
dinar

What monetary unit of Iran is equivalent to one-hundredth of a rial?
dinar

What Balkan mountain range running parallel to the Adriatic coast from Slovenia in the north-west, through Croatia, Bosnia, and Montenegro, to Albania in the south-east peaks at Maja Jezercë?
Dinaric Alps

What Kantian phrase refers to a thing as it is in itself, not mediated through perception by the senses or conceptualization, and therefore unknowable?
Ding an sich

What literary or dialectic noun refers to a deep wooded valley or dell?
dingle

What Nilotic language of people with the same name is spoken by over one million people in Sudan?
Dinka

State another name for the quelea.
dioch; weaver bird

(245--313) Faced with mounting military problems, who divided the Roman Empire between himself in the east and Maximian in the west in 286 and launched the final persecution of the Christians in 303?
Diocletian

(c. 400--c. 325 BC) This Greek philosopher lived ascetically in Athens (lived in a tub according to legend) and was accordingly nicknamed Kuōn `the dog,' from which the Cynics derived their name. Identify this most famous Cynic who emphasized self-sufficiency and the need for natural, uninhibited behaviour, regardless of social conventions?
Diogenes

What satellite of Saturn, the twelfth closest to the planet, was discovered by Cassini in 1684? The icy moon has a partly cratered and partly smooth surface and a diameter of 1,120 km.
Dione

(d. c. 250, feast day: 9 October) What Italian-born French bishop and patron saint of France --- known as ``Dionysius'' --- was one of seven missionaries sent from Rome to convert Gaul according to tradition, became bishop of Paris, and was martyred in the reign of the emperor Valerian?
St. Denis

(d. c. 556) This Scythian monk is famous for introducing the system of dates BC and AD that is still in use today, accepting 753 AUC as the year of the Incarnation, though this is inaccurate. Identify this scholar who is said to have taken his nickname ``little'' as a sign of humility.
Dionysius Exiguus

(1st century BC) What Greek historian, literary critic, and rhetorician lived in Rome from 30 BC and is best known for his detailed Greek history of the city that covers the period from the earliest times until the outbreak of the First Punic War (264 BC)?
Dionysius of Halicarnassus

According to tradition, this churchman, whose conversion by St. Paul is recorded in Acts 17.34, went on to become the first bishop of Athens. Identify this Greek, who was later confused with St. Denis and with a mystical theologian, Pseudo [---], who exercised a profound influence on medieval theology?
Dionysius the Areopagite

(fl. c. 250 AD) What Greek mathematician was the first to attempt an algebraical notation, showing in his Arithmetica how to solve simple and quadratic equations, his work leading to Fermat's discoveries in number theory?
Diophantus

What mineral occurring as white to pale green crystals in metamorphic and basic igneous rocks consists of a calcium and magnesium silicate of the pyroxene group, often containing iron and chromium?
diopside

What unit of refractive power is equal to the reciprocal of the focal length (in metres) of a given lens?
dioptre

By what name are the twins Castor and Pollux known collectively?
Dioscuri

What twins comprise Dioscuri?
Castor, Pollux

What highly toxic heterocyclic organochlorine compound produced as a byproduct in some manufacturing processes, notably herbicide production and paper bleaching, is a persistent environmental pollutant with the chemical formula C12H4O2Cl4 (TCDD)?
dioxin

Who said that ``the true logic of this world is in the calculus of probabilities''?
James Clerk Maxwell

What New Latin phrase means ``contradiction in terms'' or, literally, ``contradiction in what is added''?
contradictio in adjecto

What American philosopher of science first described the ``paradigm shift'' and was accused of plagiarism by Michael Polanyi?
Thomas Kuhn

What American physicist, Nobel laureate (1989), and Harvard professor is celebrated for his contributions to the development of atomic clocks and helped found Brookhaven and Fermilab?
Norman Ramsey

What antihistamine compound used for the symptomatic relief of allergies has the chemical formula C17H21NO?
diphenhydramine

What synthetic crystalline compound with basic properties, used in making azo dyes and as an insecticide and larvicide, has the chemical formula (C6H5)2NH?
diphenylamine

What synthetic compound used as a reagent for analyzing and separating lead and other metals has the chemical formula C13H12N4S?
dithizone

What acute and highly contagious disease that induces inflammation of the mucous membranes, formation of a false membrane in the throat that hinders breathing and swallowing, and potentially fatal heart and nerve damage by a bacterial toxin in the blood is caused by Klebs--Löffler bacillus in humans?
diphtheria

What bacterium --- a Gram-positive non-motile club-shaped rod --- sometimes causes disease in humans and other animals, including diphtheria?
corynebacterium

What sound formed by the combination of two vowels in a single syllable begins as one vowel and moves toward another?
diphthong

Define ``tutelary.''
having the guardianship of a person or a thing

What book mentioned in the Hebrew Bible, considered a lost non-canonical book, is called Sefer HaYashar?
Book of Jasher

Define ``credulity.''
readiness or willingness to believe especially on slight or uncertain evidence

What adjective is used to describe a fish's approximately symmetrical tail that has the vertebral column continuing to the tip, as in lampreys?
diphycercal

What is the paralysis of corresponding parts on both sides of the body, typically affecting the legs more severely than the arms?
diplegia

What 1695 work of Leibniz was a collection of originals of important public documents, many of which dealt with international affairs?
Codex Juris Gentium Diplomaticus

What is the technical term for double vision?
diplopia

What class of myriapod arthropods comprises the millipedes?
Diplopoda

During what stage of the prophase of meiosis --- the fourth, following the pachytene --- do the paired chromosomes begin to separate into two pairs of chromatids?
diplotene

What order of small primitive wingless insects comprises creatures resemblant of the true bristletails with two bristles at the end of the abdomen?
Diplura

What name is given to alcoholism in a form characterized by intermittent bouts of craving for alcohol?
dipsomania

What large order of insects that comprises the two-winged or true flies, which have the hindwings reduced to form balancing organs (halteres), includes many biting forms such as mosquitoes and tsetse flies that are vectors of disease?
Diptera

What adjective is used to describe something with a double peristyle?
dipteral

What architectural name is given to a row of columns surrounding a space within a building---like a court or internal garden---or edging a veranda or porch?
peristyle

What is a dipteran?
fly

What name is attributed to a painting, especially an altarpiece, on two hinged wooden panels that may be closed like a book or an ancient writing tablet consisting of two hinged leaves with waxed inner sides?
diptych

What synthetic drug used as a coronary vasodilator to treat angina also reduces platelet aggregation and hence the chance of thrombosis?
dipyridamole

What synthetic compound used in controlling plant growth, often as a non-persistent contact herbicide, has the chemical formula (C5H4NCH2)2Br2?
diquat

(1902--84) What English theoretical physicist described the properties of the electron, including its spin, and postulated the existence of the positron by applying Einstein's relativity to quantum mechanics? He won the Nobel Prize for Physics in 1933.
Paul Dirac

What monetary unit of Tajikistan is equal to one hundredth of a somoni?
diram

What large extinct wolf (Canis dirus) of the Pleistocene epoch preyed on large mammals?
dire wolf

What adjective refers to a neoclassical decorative style intermediate between the more ornate Louis XVI style and the Empire style that was prevalent during the French Directory (1795--99)?
Directoire

What name for a lament for the dead---particularly one forming part of a funeral rite---comes from the Latin for ``direct,'' the first word of an antiphon (Ps. 5.8) formerly used in the Latin Office for the Dead?
dirge

What basic monetary unit of Morocco and the United Arab Emirates is equivalent to 100 centimes in Morocco and 100 fils in the United Arab Emirates?
dirham

What monetary unit of Libya and Qatar is equal to one thousandth of a dinar in Libya and one hundredth of a riyal in Qatar?
dirham

From the Latin ``to direct,'' what noun refers to state control of economic and social matters?
dirigisme

What factor in ecclesiastical law invalidates a marriage, such as the existence of a prior marriage?
diriment impediment

What short thrusting dagger was carried by Scottish Highlanders during the Age of Sail?
dirk

What name for a full, wide skirt with a tight waistband comes from a south German word for ``girl''?
dirndl

On what island was Tycho Brahe's observatory?
Hven

What Danish astronomer was the first person to estimate the speed of light (1676) by timing the eclipses of Io?
Rømer

What two scientists---an Englishman and a Frenchman---simultaneously and independently conjectured the existence of Neptune?
John Adams, Urbain Le Verrier

Whose experiment measuring the force of gravitational attraction between pairs of lead spheres allows one to calculate the gravitational constant?
Henry Cavendish

Whose experiment exhibits the equivalence of inertial mass and gravitational mass?
Eötvös Loránd

Define ``discommode.''
cause someone trouble or inconvenience

What check results when a player moves a piece or pawn to put the opponent's king in check from another piece?
discovered check

Define ``disembogue.''
to flow or come forth from or as if from a channel

What is a female entertainer performing monologues called? The term comes from the French for ``talker.''
diseuse

What noun --- from the French for ``undressed'' --- refers to the state of being only partly or scantily clothed?
dishabille

What literary noun --- from the Italian for ``unembarrassed'' --- refers to self-assurance or lack of constraint?
disinvoltura

Define ``disinter.''
dig up

What Latin plural noun --- an alteration of a Horatian phrase --- refers to scattered fragments, especially of written work?
disjecta membra

What Horatian phrase translates to ``limbs of a dismembered poet''?
disjecti membra poetae

What does ``DOE'' abbreviate?
disk operating system

What island --- with extensive coal deposits on the western coast of Greenland --- has its chief settlement is Godhavn?
Disko

What area of swampland in southeastern Virginia and northeastern North Carolina has a depressing name?
Great Dismal Swamp

Where is Disney World located?
Lake Buena Vista

What is the condition of having a chromosome represented twice in a chromosomal complement?
disomy

What noun is associated with a belief in a system of historical progression, as revealed in the Bible, consisting of a series of stages in God's self-revelation and plan of salvation?
dispensationalism

What animal or human activity that seems inappropriate to the context, such as head-scratching when one is confused, is considered to arise unconsciously when a conflict between antagonistic urges cannot be resolved?
displacement activity

In what chemical reaction is a substance simultaneously oxidized and reduced, giving two different products?
disproportionation

What word refers to either debate or an academic exercise in oral defence of a thesis by formal logic?
disputation

Define ``disparate.''
essentially different in kind; not allowing comparison

What British statesman --- prime minister 1868 and 1874--80 --- was primarily responsible for introducing the second Reform Act (1867), ensured that Britain bought a controlling interest in the Suez Canal (1875), and made Queen Victoria empress of India?
Benjamin Disraeli

What verb means to reduce a sailor to a lower rank?
disrate

What name is given to part of a plant that serves to propagate it, such as a seed or a fruit?
disseminule

Define ``dissension.''
disagreement that leads to discord

What botanical and zoological term refers to a partition in a part or organ, such as a septum?
dissepiment

What linguistic verb means to change a sound in a word to be unlike the sounds near it?
dissimilate

Define ``dissimilitude.''
dissimilarity; diversity

What verb from the Latin for ``hidden'' or ``concealed'' means ``to conceal or disguise one's thoughts, feelings, or character''?
dissimulate

What mental condition is characterized by the existence of two or more different personality states, with distinct behaviour, memory, and cognition, in one individual?
dissociative identity disorder

What is the opposite of persuasion?
dissuasion

What is the technical term for the symmetrical relation of mirror images, the left and right hands, or crystals with two corresponding forms?
dissymmetry

Who said, ``The limit of my language is the limit of my world''?
Ludwig Wittgenstein

What word from the Latin for ``makeweight'' refers to the part of a logarithm that follows the decimal point or the part of a floating-point number that represents the significant digits of that number?
mantissa

Onto what stick or spindle is wool or flax wound for spinning?
distaff

To what does ``the distaff side'' refer?
the female side of a family

What anatomical adjective means ``situated away from the centre of the body or from the point of attachment''?
distal

What is a distich?
pair of verse lines; couplet

What American or British military decoration is awarded for heroism or distinguished achievement while on aerial duty?
Distinguished Flying Cross

What name is attributed to a belief in two gods, especially as independent and opposed principles of good and evil?
ditheism

What synthetic compound that is used as a reagent for the analysis and separation of lead and other metals has the chemical formula C13H12N4S?
dithizone

To whom were dithyrambs dedicated?
Dionysus

What term refers to a mistaken repetition of a letter, word, or phrase by a copyist?
dittography

What literary verb from the Latin for ``wandered about'' means ``stray or digress''?
divagate

What Hindu festival of lights, held from October to November, is mainly associated with Lakshmi, the goddess of prosperity, and marks the beginning of the fiscal year in India?
Diwali

What name was given to the privy council of the Ottoman Empire or a legislative body elsewhere in the Middle East?
divan

What technical or literary verb from the Latin for ``stretched apart'' means stretch, spread apart, or diverge widely?
divaricate

What Indic language --- also called Maldivian --- is spoken in the Maldives?
Divehi

What word refers to a blind tube leading from a cavity or passage or --- in medicine --- an abnormal sac or pouch formed at a weak point in the wall of the alimentary tract?
diverticulum

What short dance within a ballet displays a dancer's technical skill without advancing the plot or character development?
divertissement

What literary noun refers to a typical or hypothetical rich man?
Dives

What is divestiture?
the action or process of selling off subsidiary business interests or investments

What doctrine that kings derive their authority from God, not from their subjects---from which it follows that rebellion is the worst of political crimes---was claimed in Britain by the earlier Stuarts and is also associated with the absolutism of Louis XIV of France?
divine right of kings

In what open-bottomed chamber supplied with compressed air can a person be let down underwater?
diving bell

What small, stocky seabird resemblant of an auk --- genus Pelecanoides --- has black upper parts and white underparts and frequents southern oceans?
diving petrel

What refers to a piece of turf cut out of the ground by a golf club?
divot

Define ``divulge.''
to make known (something private or sensitive)

What name is given to a central finance department, chief administrative office, or regional governing body in Islamic societies?
diwan

What term that originated in New Orleans in the early twentieth century refers to a kind of jazz with a solid two-beat rhythm and collective improvisation?
Dixieland

What Turkish city on the Tigris --- historically Amida --- whose modern spelling refers to its region's abundance of copper is the capital of a province of the same name?
Diyarbakir

Define ``endogenous.''
having an internal cause or origin

What are fraternal twins called?
dizygotic

What was Jakarta called before 1949?
Batavia

What is the colloquial Arabic form for ``mountain''?
jebel

What loose hooded --- typically woollen --- cloak with full sleeves whose name is of Moroccan Arabic origin is traditionally worn by Arabs?
djellaba

What is a djembe?
goblet-shaped hand drum originating in West Africa

What intelligent spirit of lower rank than the angels of Arabian and Muslim mythology can appear in human and animal forms and possess humans?
jinn

What does ``DLL'' abbreviate in computing?
dynamic link library (a collection of subroutines stored on disk, which can be loaded into memory and executed when accessed by a running program)

What acetylcholinesterase inhibitor is used as a topical treatment for skin wrinkles and sometimes suggested to be helpful in certain mental conditions?
DMAE (dimethylaminoethanol)

What severe form of muscular dystrophy---named after the French neurologist who first described it---is caused by a genetic defect and usually affects boys?
Duchenne muscular dystrophy

What law states that for every proposition, either it or its negation is true?
law of the excluded middle

What river in eastern Europe rises in Russia west of Moscow and flows south for about 2,200 km through Ukraine to the Black Sea?
Dnipro

What industrial city and river port in Ukraine was called ``Kamenskoye'' until 1936?
Dniprodzerzhinsk

What industrial city and river port in Ukraine was called ``Yekaterinoslav'' until 1926?
Dnipropetrovsk

What does DNR abbreviate?
do not resuscitate

What mechanism attached to a loom for weaving small patterns is similar to but more simple than those produced by a Jacquard loom?
dobby

What rich cake made of alternate layers of sponge and chocolate or mocha cream with a crisp caramel topping is named after a Hungarian pastry cook?
Dobos torte

What basic monetary unit of São Tomé and Principe is equal to 100 centavos?
dobra

What district of eastern Romania and northeastern Bulgaria on the Black Sea coast is bounded on the north and west by the Danube River?
Dobruja

What unit of measurement for the total amount of ozone in the atmosphere above a point on the earth's surface is equivalent to a layer of pure ozone 0.01 mm thick at standard temperature and pressure?
Dobson unit

What Gnostic doctrine supposes that Christ's body was not human, but either a phantasm or of celestial substance, so his sufferings were only apparent?
Docetism

When is St. Alphonsus Liguori's feast day?
1 August

What lattice refers to the fourteen different three-dimensional configurations into which atoms can be arranged in crystals?
Bravais lattice

What is the generalization of the parallelepiped and parallelogram called?
parallelotope

What name is given to a partition of a plane with points into convex polygons such that each polygon contains exactly one generating point and every point in a given polygon is closer to its generating point than to any other?
Voronoi diagram

What name is attributed to the number of equivalent hyperspheres that can touch an equivalent hypersphere without any intersections?
kissing number

What surveying instrument has a rotating telescope for measuring horizontal and vertical angles?
theodolite

What teacher of St. Thomas Aquinas is known as ``Doctor Universalis''?
St. Albertus Magnus

To a first approximation, the London force between two molecules is inversely proportional to what power of the distance of separation?
seventh

In what four ``mythologically inseparable'' manners do threats to the stability of cultural tradition tend to occupy?
rapid natural environmental shift, contact with an isolated foreign culture, application of novel linguistically or episodically mediated critical skill, revolutionary heroic activity

Define ``senescent.''
deteriorating; old; mature

Let $f$ be a map from a set $A$ to a set $B$. If $f(A) = B$, then what is $f$ called?
surjective

Let $f$ be a map from a set $A$ to a set $B$. If the pre-image of every element in $B$ under $f$ consists of at most one element, then what is $f$ called?
injective

What template sets out the format and tag structure of an XML- or SGML-compliant document?
document type definition (DTD)

How many faces does a dodecahedron have?
twelve

What shape are the faces of a dodecahedron?
pentagon

Of what group of twelve islands is Rhodes the largest?
Dodecanese

What city in southwestern Kansas was established in 1872 as a railhead on the Santa Fe Trail and rapidly gained a reputation as a rowdy frontier town?
Dodge City

What burrowing bivalve mollusk (family Glycimeridae) has a highly convex, almost spherical shell?
dog cockle

What name was given to the chief magistrate of Venice or Genoa?
doge

What small pointed ornament is repeated along a moulding consisting of four petals radiating from a raised centre, used primarily in the Early English style?
dogtooth

What phrase from Shakespeare's Julius Caesar (3.1.276) refers to the havoc accompanying military conflict?
the dogs of war

What canine proverb means that you cannot make people change their established opinion and behaviour patterns?
you can't teach an old dog new tricks

What canine proverb means that everyone will have good luck or success at some point in their lives?
every dog has its day

What does ``DOHC'' abbreviate?
double overhead camshaft

What does ``DOI'' abbreviate?
digital object identifier

What Italian phrase refers to pleasant idleness --- literally ``sweet doing nothing''?
dolce far niente

If you have a relatively long skull, with what adjective might someone describe you?
dolichocephalic

From what Dickens novel is the sentence ``Silas Wegg, being on his road to the Roman Empire, approaches it by way of Clerkenwell''?
Our mutual friend

Who coined the term ``cultural capital''?
Pierre Bourdieu

Who said that ``the judges were right when they finally told the accused that all [Eichmann] had said was `empty talk'''?
Hannah Arendt

What is repetition at the end of successive clauses called?
epistrophe

What is the repetition of the end of a clause at the beginning of the following clause called?
anadiplosis

What countries bound France?
Andorra, Belgium, Germany, Italy, Luxembourg, Monaco, Spain, Switzerland

What city and country produce the finest china?
Limoges, France/Severes, France/Dresden, Germany/Copenhagen, Denmark

Where is the River Volga?
Russia

What is the finest cotton grown?
Sea Island cotton/Egyptian cotton

What country consumed the most tea before the war?
Russia

What city in the United States leads in making laundry machines?
Chicago

What city is the fur centre of the United States?
St. Louis/New York

(1842--1923) What Scottish chemist and physicist devised the vacuum flask, achieved temperatures close to absolute zero, and was the first to produce liquid oxygen and hydrogen in quantity?
Sir James Dewar

Where is Copenhagen?
Denmark

Where is Spitsbergen?
Svalbard, Norway

To what country other than Australia are kangaroos native?
Papua New Guinea

Who was Bessemer and what did he do?
English engineer who invented a process for making steel by taking carbon out of molten iron by the air blast

Whence do we get prunes?
Santa Clara Valley and elsewhere

Who was John Hancock?
the first signer of the Declaration of Independence

Who was Plutarch?
Greek of the first and second centuries AD who wrote Parallel lives

Who was Hannibal?
the Carthaginian general who conquered most of Italy in the third century BC

Who was Danton?
French Revolutionary orator who was sent to the guillotine by the Committee of Terror

Who was Solon?
Athenian lawgiver, famous for twenty-three centuries for the remark to Croesus (that modern historians say he did not make) to ``Count no man happy until he is dead''

Who was Francis Marion?
principal leader of the Revolutionary forces in the Southern States

Who was Leonidas?
the Spartan general who led the heroic defence of Thermopylae

Where did the United States get Louisiana from?
France

Who was Pizarro?
the Spanish conqueror of Peru

Who was Bolívar?
the hero of the South American wars of liberation from Spain

What war material did Chile export to the Allies during the war?
nitrates

Where does most coffee come from?
Brazil

Where was Napoleon born?
Ajaccio, Corsica

What is the highest rise of tide on the North American Coast?
seventy feet in the Bay of Fundy

Who invented logarithms?
John Napier

Who was the Emperor of Mexico when Cortez landed?
Montezuma

Where is the Imperial Valley?
Southern California on the Mexican border

What is the Imperial Valley noted for?
melons

What and where is the Sargasso Sea?
vast tract of seaweed in the North Atlantic Ocean

Name a large inland body of water that has no outlet.
Great Salt Lake

What is the capital of Pennsylvania?
Harrisburg

Rhode Island is the smallest state. What is the next?
Delaware

What is the third-smallest state?
Connecticut

How far is it from New York to Liverpool?
3,167.5 nautical miles

Of what state is Helena the capital?
Montana

Of what state is Tallahassee the capital?
Florida

What state has the largest amethyst mines?
Virginia

What is the name of a famous violin maker (the most prominent one)?
Stradivarius

Who invented the modern paper-making machine?
Robert (not Fourdrinier)

Who invented the typesetting machine?
Mergenthaler

How is leather tanned?
by immersion in an infusion of oak or hemlock bark or other material strong in tannic acid

What is artificial silk made from?
cotton or wood pulp treated with acids and drawn into threads

What is a caisson?
enclosure to keep water from seeping or flowing into a space where engineering operations are taking place

What is shellac?
base for varnish made from lac, which is resinous incrustation formed on certain trees in the East Indies by an insect resembling the cochineal

What is celluloid made from?
wood pulp (primarily)

What causes the tides?
the gravitational pull of the moon exerted powerfully on the ocean because of its fluidity, and weakly on the earth because of its comparative rigidity

What is coke?
coal after the more volatile components have been driven from it by heat

From what part of the North Atlantic do we get codfish?
off the Newfoundland Banks

What is a monsoon?
seasonal prevailing wind in the region of South and Southeast Asia, blowing from the southwest in summer and from the northeast in winter

From where do we import figs?
Smyrna

Where do we get our domestic sardines?
California, Maine

Where is Kenosha?
Wisconsin

What is the speed of sound in dry air at freezing?
1,091 feet/second

What is the speed of sound in water?
4,680 feet/second

Who was Cleopatra and how did she die?
queen of Egypt and contemporary of Julius Caesar and Mark Antony who committed suicide by making an asp bite her

Where are condors found?
Andes

Who discovered the law of gravitation?
Sir Isaac Newton

What is the distance between the earth and sun?
93,100,000 miles

Why is cast iron called pig iron?
fancied resemblance of the row of channels into which the molten flows to a litter of pigs

Who discovered radium?
Marie Curie

Who discovered the X-ray?
Roentgen

What is the capital of Alabama?
Montgomery

Who composed Il trovatore?
Verdi

Where is platinum found?
Ural Mountains

From where do we get sulphur?
Louisiana, Texas

Who discovered how to vulcanize rubber?
Charles Goodyear

What is vulcanite and how is it made?
black variety of hard rubber capable of being cut and polished, made from the cheaper grades of rubber from Borneo and Java vulcanized with much sulphur

Who invented the cotton gin?
Eli Whitney

What is the difference between anthracite and bituminous coal?
hard coal is anthracite and soft coal is bituminous

From where do we get benzol?
fractional distillation of coal tar

What is a foot pound?
unit of energy equal to the work done in raising one pound of avoirdupois against the force of gravity one foot

Where is the St. Gothard pass?
Alps

Who wrote Les miserables?
Victor Hugo

Who made ``The thinker''?
Auguste Rodin

What is copra?
dried kernel of the coconut

What is the heaviest kind of wood?
lignum vitae

What is the lightest wood?
basswood/balsa

What Swedish chemist discovered glycerol, chlorine, and oxygen?
Carl Wilhelm Scheele

Who was the first person reliably documented to have used light-sensitive chemicals to capture silhouette images on durable media such as paper and the first known to have attempted to photograph the image formed in a camera obscura?
Thomas Wedgwood

What English-born American scientist, philosopher, physician, chemist, historian, and photographer is credited with producing the first clear photograph of a female face and the first detailed photograph of the moon in 1840?
John William Draper

What large hat with one side drooping and with a floral trimming, formerly worn by women, is named after a character in Dickens's Barnaby Rudge?
Dolly Varden

What dish consisting of ingredients such as meat and spiced rice wrapped in vine or cabbage leaves is popular in the Balkans, the Caucasus, and the eastern Mediterranean?
dolma

What megalithic tomb with a large flat stone laid on upright ones is found chiefly in Britain and France?
dolmen

What literary noun refers to a state of great sorrow or distress?
dolour

What Spanish politician and leader of the Republicans during the Spanish Civil War is known as ``La Pasionaria''?
Dolores Ibárruri Gómez

What title is prefixed to the names of some Roman Catholic dignitaries and Benedictine and Carthusian monks?
Dom

What word from the French for ``estate'' refers to a vineyard?
domaine

What comprehensive record of the extent, value, ownership, and liabilities of land in England was made in 1086 by order of William I?
Domesday

What word from the French for ``servant'' refers to a cyclist in a road racing team whose role is to help their team leader during a race, for example, by setting the pace or creating a slipstream?
domestique

What formal word refers to the country that a person treats as their permanent home or lives in and has a substantial connection with?
domicile

(c. 1170--1221, feast day: 8 August) What Spanish priest and friar founded the Order of Friars Preachers at Toulouse in France in 1216, whose members became known as ``Black Friars''?
St. Dominic

What name is given to any of the seven letters A--G used in church calendars to indicate the date (1--7 January) on which the first Sunday in the year falls, hence in dating movable feasts?
dominical letter

Who was the son of Vespasian and the younger brother of Titus?
Domitian

What Sinhalese statesman and prime minister presided over Ceylon's achievement of full dominion status within the Commonwealth?
Don Stephen Senanayake

(1386--1466) What Italian sculptor was one of the pioneers of scientific perspective and is known for his lifelike sculptures, including the bronze David (c. 1430--60)?
Donatello

(1444--1514) What Italian architect drew up the first plan for St. Peter's Cathedral, which was begun in 1506, and established the concept of a large central dome?
Donato Bramante

What series of Lower Pleistocene glaciations in the Alps preceded the Günz?
Donau

What basic monetary unit of Vietnam is equal to 100 xu?
dong

What river in Vietnam flows for 483 km from south-central Vietnam to join the Saigon River below Ho Chi Minh City?
Dong-nai River

(1797--1848) What Italian composer's operas include tragedies such as Lucia di Lammermoor (1835) and comedies such as Don Pasquale (1843)?
Gaetano Donizetti

What is the great tower or innermost keep of a castle called?
donjon

What equilibrium is reached between two ionic solutions separated by a semipermeable membrane when one or more of the kinds of ion present cannot pass through the membrane, resulting in a difference in osmotic pressure and electrical potential between the solutions?
Donnan equilibrium

What British proverb means ``don't risk the failure of a large project by trying to economize on trivial things''?
don't spoil the ship for a ha'p'orth of tar

What German-derived noun means ``enjoyment obtained from the troubles of others''?
schadenfreude

What word from the Greek for ``all-healing'' refers to ``a remedy for all ills or difficulties''?
panacea

What word refers to ``social instability resulting from a breakdown of standards and values'' or ``personal unrest, alienation, and uncertainty that comes from a lack of purpose or ideals''?
anomie

What does Matthew 13.35 say?
This was to fulfill what was spoken by the prophet: ``I will open my mouth in parables; I will utter what has been hidden since the foundation of the world.''

What resort region (``peninsula'') in northeastern Wisconsin lies between Green Bay and Lake Michigan?
Door Peninsula

What ``reward pathway'' compound --- chemical formula C8H11NO2 --- is present in the body as a neurotransmitter and a precursor of other substances such as epinephrine?
dopamine

What is a flock of shelduck called?
dopping

A dopping is a flock of what?
shelduck

Where was Doppler from?
Austria

What southern constellation (the Goldfish) contains most of the Large Magellanic Cloud?
Dorado

What is another term for mahimahi?
dorado

(1906--88) What Hungarian-born American composer and conductor was the musical director of symphonies in Dallas (1945--49), Minneapolis (1949--60), Stockholm (1966--70), Washington, DC (1970--77), and Detroit (1977--81)?
Doráti Antal

What river in western France rises in the Auvergne region and flows west for 472 km to meet the Garonne River and form the Gironde estuary?
Dordogne

What industrial city and river port in the Netherlands near the mouth of the Rhine River is 19 km southeast of Rotterdam?
Dordrecht

What mode is represented by the natural diatonic scale D--D?
Dorian

What is the passing of the Virgin Mary from earthly life called?
Dormition

What prehistoric culture flourished in the American Arctic during the first millennium AD and was displaced by the Thule culture?
Dorset

What rare word from the Greek for ``spear carrier'' refers to a pedantic and annoyingly persistent critic?
doryphore

(c. 205--270) What philosopher, probably of Roman descent, was the founder and leading exponent of Neoplatonism?
Plotinus

Why can ``spiritual wisdom'' be ``reduced to'' narrative form?
the word has a deceptively simple, yet infinitely meaningful ``triggering'' property (254)

Why is the word in ``meaningful context'' meaningful?
it provides information relevant to episodic representation per se and it has behavioural relevance

What name is given to each of three energies believed to circulate in the body and govern physiological activity?
dosha

What device is used to measure an absorbed dose of ionizing radiation?
dosimeter

What ornamental cloth is hung behind an altar in a church or at the sides of a chancel?
dossal

What English translation of the Bible formerly used in the Roman Catholic Church was completed at a commune of the same name in France early in the seventeenth century?
Douay Bible

Whose Nova Stereometria dolorium vinariorum `New solid geometry of wine barrels,' inspired by a wine barrel seller's use of the gauge rod leading up to his second wedding in Linz, explored integral calculus?
Johannes Kepler

(feast day: 21 December) What apostle acquired his nickname because he said that he would not believe that Jesus had risen again until he had seen and touched his wounds (John 20.24--29)?
St. Thomas

What river on the Iberian peninsula rises in central Spain and flows west for 900 km through Portugal to the Atlantic Ocean near Oporto?
Douro

Define ``dour.''
stern, harsh; obstinate, unyielding; gloomy, sullen

What name is given to either a true sole that is common in European waters (Solea solea, family Soleidae) or a relative of the lemon sole found in the eastern Pacific (Microstomus pacificus, family Pleuronectidae)?
Dover sole

Name the six counties of Northern Ireland.
Antrim, Armagh, Down, Fermanagh, Londonderry, Tyrone

What is the reduction at the cellular level of the magnitude or rate of a physiological response or a biochemical process, especially of the expression of a gene, or the reduction of the number or density of cell surface receptors for a physiologically active substance, causing a decrease in sensitivity in response to persistent exposure, called?
downregulation

What bacterial antibiotic widely used to treat leukemia and various other forms of cancer is produced by the bacterium Streptomyces peucetius caesius?
doxorubicin

What broad-spectrum antibiotic of the tetracycline group has a long half-life in the body?
doxycycline

What French-derived word refers to the most respected or prominent person in a particular field?
doyen

(1859--1930) What Scottish novelist and short-story writer is known for his creation of private detective Sherlock Holmes, who first appeared (with his friend Dr. Watson, the narrator of the stories) in A study in Scarlet (1887), The adventures of Sherlock Holmes (1892), and The hound of the Baskervilles (1902)?
Sir Arthur Conan Doyle

(1844--1901) What English impresario and producer brought together the librettist Sir W. S. Gilbert and the composer Sir Arthur Sullivan, producing many of their operettas in London's Savoy Theatre that he had established in 1881?
Richard D'Oyly Carte

What combined vaccine (an abbreviation for the three things it treats) is given to small children?
DPT

What does ``DPT'' abbreviate?
diphtheria, pertussis, tetanus

What was Dr. Seuss's name?
Theodor Seuss Geisel

What unit of weight, formerly used by apothecaries, is equivalent to 60 grains or 1/8 of an ounce?
drachma

What large northern constellation (the Dragon) with no bright stars stretches around the north celestial pole and represents the dragon killed by Hercules?
Draco

(7th century BC) What Athenian legislator's codification of Athenian law was notorious for its severity?
Draco

Who penned Dracula?
Bram Stoker

What literary noun refers to the damp remains of malt after brewing often used as an appetizer or supplement in animal rations?
draff

What word refers to either a sugar-coated nut or a small silver-coloured decorative ball?
dragée

What name is attributed to one of a series of persecutions directed by Louis XIV against French Protestants in which troops were quartered upon them?
dragonnade

In what pharmacological test is a substance introduced into the eye or applied to the skin of a laboratory animal to ascertain the likely effect of that substance on the corresponding human tissue?
Draize test

(c. 1540--96) What sailor and explorer was the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe (1577--80) on the Golden Hind and played a crucial part in the defeat of the Spanish Armada?
Sir Francis Drake

What speculative equation estimates the likelihood of discovering intelligent extraterrestrial life in the galaxy, expressed as the product of a series of factors such as the number of stars, the fraction of stars with planets, the fraction of planets on which life evolves, the average lifetime of a civilization, etc.?
Drake equation

What area of ocean, noted for its violent storms, connects the South Atlantic Ocean with the South Pacific Ocean and separates the southern tip of South America (Cape Horn) from the Antarctic Peninsula?
Drake Passage

What mountain range in southern Africa, whose highest peak is Thabana Ntlenyana, stretches northeast for 1,126 km through Lesotho and parts of South Africa?
Drakensberg Mountains

What trademarked antihistamine compound is used to counter nausea, especially travel sickness?
Dramamine

What is the theory and practice of dramatic composition?
dramaturgy

What sweet Scotch whiskey liqueur's name comes from the Scottish Gaelic for ``satisfying drink''?
Drambuie

What was the former German policy of eastward expansion, especially that espoused under Nazi rule, called?
Drang nach Osten

What river rises in northern Italy and flows for 725 km through southern Austria, Slovenia, and Croatia to join the Danube River near Osijek and forms part of the border between Hungary and Croatia?
Drava River

What type of battleship that was introduced in the early twentieth century was larger and faster than its predecessors and equipped entirely with large-calibre guns?
dreadnought

dreamwork

On what river is Dresden?
Elbe

What is the capital of Saxony?
Dresden

Alfred Dreyfus

What river flows for 459 km partly along the border between Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia into the Sava River west of Belgrade in Serbia?
Drina River

What device, typically conical or funnel-shaped with open ends, towed behind a boat, an aircraft, or another moving object to reduce speed or improve stability?
drogue

What is the alleged right of a medieval feudal lord to have sexual intercourse with a vassal's bride on her wedding night called?
droit de seigneur

What carnivorous bipedal dinosaur of a late Cretaceous family that included deinonychus and the velociraptors had a large slashing claw on each hind foot?
dromaeosaurid

What low four-wheeled open carriage was used in Russia?
droshky

What is the site in London of the Theatre Royal?
Drury Lane

What is an electric cell in which the electrolyte is absorbed in a solid to form a paste, preventing spillage, called?
dry cell

What island group in southwestern Florida, west of Key West, is noted for its wildlife?
Dry Tortugas

What common polypore growing on tree stumps and logs with a scaly, yellowish-brown upper surface is found in both North America and Eurasia and edible when young?
dryad saddle

(1631--1700) What English poet, critic, and playwright of the Augustan Age is best known for Marriage à la mode (1673), All for love (1678), and Absalom and Achitophel (1681)?
John Dryden

What fossil anthropoid ape of the middle Miocene to early Pliocene epochs includes the supposed common ancestor of gorillas, chimpanzees, and humans?
Dryopithecus

In what process is a print bonded to a mount using a layer of adhesive in a hot press?
dry mounting

The Leech lattice is defined in [---] dimensions.
24

What is the only nontrivial case of the sum of the first $n$ squares being a square?
$n = 24$

What unit of electric potential is $c_{\text{cgs}} 10^{-8}$ volt?
statvolt

Tod

decessit sine prole `died without issue'

Du Fu

(1834--96) What French-born novelist, cartoonist, and illustrator is chiefly remembered for his novel Trilby (1894), which included the character Svengali and gave rise to the word ``Svengali'' for a person with a hypnotic influence on another?
George du Maurier

(1921--92) What Czech statesman---the first secretary of the Czechoslovak Communist Party (1968--69)---was the driving force behind the political reforms of 1968 that prompted the Soviet invasion of Czechoslovakia in 1968 and his removal from office and elected speaker of the federal assembly in the new Czechoslovak parliament after the collapse of communism in 1989?
Alexander Dubček

(1901--85) What French painter rejected traditional techniques and incorporated materials such as sand and plaster in his paintings and produced sculptures made from garbage?
Jean Dubuffet

Duc de Saint-Simon

Marcel Duchamp

(1877--1953) What French painter and textile designer's characteristic style involved calligraphic outlines sketched on brilliant background washes?
Raoul Dufy

DUKW

What extract of woody nightshade is used in homeopathy for treating skin diseases and chest complaints?
dulcamara

What traditional Argentinian dessert is made by caramelizing sugar in milk?

dulcian

What stringed instrument of trapezoidal shape is played with light hammers held in the hands?
dulcimer

dulcitone

What is the reverence accorded to saints and angels in Roman Catholicism?
dulia

What name is ascribed to the practice by slave-making ants of capturing the pupae of other ant species and rearing them as workers of their own colony?
dulosis

What rare blue or violet mineral typically occurs as needles and fibrous masses in gneiss and schist and consists of an aluminum and iron borosilicate?
dumortierite

What is the theoretical limit to the number of people with whom any individual can sustain a stable or meaningful social relationship?
Dunbar's number

``By all means, marry. If you get a good wife, you'll be happy. If you get a bad one, you'll become a philosopher.'' Who said this?
Socrates

``I can calculate the motion of heavenly bodies, but not the madness of people.'' Who said this?
Sir Isaac Newton

``My doctrine shall drop as the rain, my speech shall distil as the dew, as the small rain upon the tender herb, and as the showers upon the grass.'' From what is this?
Deut. 32.2

``History repeats itself, first as tragedy, second as farce.'' Who said this?
Karl Marx

``Our Constitution was made only for a moral and religious people. It is wholly inadequate to the government of any other.'' Who said this?
John Adams

``Politics is the ability to foretell what is going to happen tomorrow, next week, next month, and next year. And to have the ability afterwards to explain why it didn't happen.'' Who said this?
Winston Churchill

``To write well, express yourself like the common people, but think like a wise man.'' Who said this?
Aristotle

``A man has free choice to the extent that he is rational.'' Who said this?
St. Thomas Aquinas

``Though the Earth, and all inferior Creatures be common to all Men, yet every Man has a Property in his own Person. This no Body has any Right to but himself.'' Who said this?
John Locke

``Iron sharpeneth iron; so a man sharpeneth the countenance of his friend.'' What is this from?
Prov. 27.17

``I would rather be stricken blind / Than to live without expression of mind.'' Who said this?
Tupac Shakur

Fatti non foste a viver come bruti ma per sequir virtute e canoscenza. `You were not made to live like brute beasts, but to pursure virtue and knowledge.' Who wrote this?
Dante Alighieri

Mark Twain

Who says that ``brevity is the soul of wit'' in Shakespeare's Hamlet?
Polonius (2.2.90)

``Madness is rare in the individual --- but with groups, parties, peoples, and ages it is the rule.'' Who said this?
Friedrich Nietzsche

``As the family goes, so goes the nation, and so goes the whole world in which we live.'' Who said this?
Pope John Paul II

``Everyone thinks of changing the world, but no one thinks of changing himself.'' Who said this?
Leo Tolstoy

``The mathematician is only complete insofar as he feels within himself the beauty of the true.'' Who said this?
Goethe

``The press today is an army with carefully organized weapons, the journalists its officers, the readers its soldiers. The reader neither knows nor is supposed to know the purposes for which he is used and the role he is to play.'' Who said this?
Oswald Spengler

``The great epochs of our lives come when we gain the courage to rechristen our evil as what is best in us.'' Identify the author.
Nietzsche

``Since he takes rules literally and things of good only in terms of obedience, the child will at first evaluate acts not in accordance with the motive that has prompted them but in terms of their exact conformity with established rules.'' Identify the author.
Piaget

Lao Tzu

What does Matthew 5.17 say?
Think not that I am come to destroy the law, or the prophets: I am not come to destroy, but to fulfil.

``Against stupidity the very gods / Themselves contend in vain.'' Identify the author.
Schiller (The Maid of Orleans)

``Days of absence, sad and dreary, / Clothed in sorrow's dark array,--- / Days of absence, I am weary: / She I love is far away.'' Identify the author.
Rousseau

Voltaire (Le Mondain)

Voltaire (Dialogue xiv. Le Chapon et la Poularde)

Alain René Le Sage (Gil Blas)

Who wrote Gil Blas?
Alain René Le Sage

``Happy who in his verse can gently steer / From grave to light, from pleasant to severe.'' Identify the author.
Nicholas Boileau-Despreaux (The Art of Poetry)

Pascal (Pensées)

``Although I am a pious man, I am not the less a man.'' Identify the author.
Molière (Le Tartuffe)

``The spiritual virtue of a sacrament is like light --- although it passes among the impure, it is not polluted.'' Identify the author.
St. Augustine

Athenæus

Marcus Aurelius

Pliny the Elder

Define ``dysarthria.''
difficulty in articulating words due to disease of the central nervous system

dyslalia

Define ``dyspraxia.''
impairment of the ability to perform coordinated movements

In what tennis racket grip are the bottom knuckle of the index finger and the heel of the hand in contact with the top of the handle, typically used for flat forehand shots?
eastern grip

In what tennis racket grip is the bottom knuckle of the index finger in contact with the top of the handle and the heel of the hand with the bevel immediately clockwise from it (for a right-handed player)?
continental grip

In what tennis racket grip is the heel of the hand in contact with the bottom of the handle, and does the bottom knuckle of the index finger touch the bevel immediately counterclockwise from it, typically used to generate heavy topspin (for a right-handed player)?
western grip

Identify the author: ``Most of what displays itself in the showcases, for example, as `objectivity,' `being scientific,' `l'art pour l'art,' `pure knowledge, free of will,' is merely dressed-up skepticism and paralysis of the will.''
Nietzsche

What adjective describes something with an animal's form?
theriomorphic

What Latin phrase refers to the line or stem through the earth's centre connecting its surface to the underworld and the heavens and around which the universe revolves?
axis mundi

Define ``chthonic.''
of or relating to the underworld

What figure in Greek mythos was a guide of souls to the place of the dead?
psychopomp

What five parts comprise Burke's dramatistic life cycle?
order, pollution, guilt, purification, redemption

According to Burke, via what three things might we be absolved from guilt (purified)?
mortification, transcendence, victimage

What are the elements of Burke's dramaturgic Pentad?
act, agents, agency, scene, purpose

What is the difference between purpose and motive in Burke's theory of ``life as drama''?
purpose addresses why the agents broke a rule; motive justifies the rule-breaking activity in terms of element ratios

(1898--1962) This mathematician --- advised by Herglotz and Hölder --- is considered the founder of modern abstract algebra with Emmy Noether. His notable students include John Tate, Serge Lang, Max Zorn, and Bernard Dwork. Identify this Austrian who contributed to class field theory --- note his reciprocity law that partially solved Hilbert's ninth problem --- developed a new construction of $L$-functions, contributed to the theories of rings, groups, and fields --- he is the eponym a ring that satisfies the descending chain condition on ideals --- resolved Hilbert's seventeenth problem, developed the theory of braids (1925), and was an expositor of Galois theory and group-cohomological class ring theory.
Emil Artin

What name is given to the central core of the primary meristem of a plant --- that, according to the histogen theory, gives rise to the stele --- or to the stelar region in a root tip?
plerome

What is eau de Nil?
pale greenish colour

What is eau-de-vie?
brandy

What layer of the ionosphere can reflect medium-frequency radio waves?
E layer

(1911--77) What German economist and conservationist's Small is beautiful: economics as if people mattered (1973) argues that mass production needs to be replaced by smaller, more energy-efficient enterprises?
E. F. Schumacher

What does EBCDIC abbreviate?
Extended Binary Coded Decimal Interchange Code

What city in ancient Syria, situated to the southwest of Aleppo, became very powerful in the third millennium BC when it dominated a region corresponding to modern Lebanon, northern Syria, and southeastern Turkey?
Ebla

What river in northeastern Spain rises in the mountains of the Cantabria region and flows southeast for 910 km into the Mediterranean Sea?
Ebro

What herpesvirus that causes infectious mononucleosis is associated with certain cancers such as Burkitt's lymphoma?
Epstein--Barr virus

What does EBV abbreviate?
Epstein--Barr virus

What name is ascribed to a painting of Jesus Christ wearing the crown of thorns?
Ecce Homo

What is the discolouration of the skin resulting from bleeding underneath, typically caused by bruising, called?
ecchymosis

(1903--97) What Australian physiologist who demonstrated how nerve impulses are conducted by means of chemical neurotransmitters won the Nobel Prize for Physiology or Medicine (1963) with Alan L. Hodgkin and Andrew F. Huxley?
Sir John Carew Eccles

What adjective describes multicellular glands that do not lose cytoplasm in their secretions, especially the sweat glands found widely distributed on the skin?
eccrine

What does ``ECCS'' abbreviate?
emergency core cooling system

What is the process of shedding the old skin (in reptiles) or casting off the outer cuticle (in insects and other arthropods) called?
ecdysis

What steroid hormone controls molting in insects and other arthropods?
ecdysone

What is an echinoid?
sea urchin

What phylum of marine invertebrates that includes starfishes, sea urchins, brittlestars, crinoids, and sea cucumbers is characterized by fivefold radial symmetry, a calcareous skeleton, and tube feet operated by fluid pressure?
Echinodermata

What small phylum of wormlike marine invertebrates comprises the spoonworms?
Echiura

What nymph was deprived of speech by Hera to stop her chatter and left able only to repeat what others had said?
Echo

What is the meaningless repetition of words just spoken by another person as a symptom of a mental condition called?
echolalia

In what condition does one or more convulsions occur in a pregnant woman suffering from high blood pressure, often followed by a coma and posing a threat to the health of mother and baby?
eclampsia

What is a metamorphic rock containing granular minerals, typically garnet and pyroxene, called?
eclogite

What entomological verb means ``emerge as an adult from the pupa or as a larva from the egg''?
eclose

(1932--2016) What Italian novelist and semiotician wrote A theory of semiotics (1976), The name of the rose (1981), and Travels in hyperreality (1986)?
Umberto Eco

What is the gradual, continuous change in the species composition between two ecosystems or communities of organisms across an environmental gradient called?
ecocline

What word that means ``flayed'' in French refers to a painting or sculpture of a human figure with the skin removed to display the musculature?
écorché

In what energetic country dance in duple time---whose name comes from the French for ``Scottish''---do couples form lines facing each other?
ecossaise

What is the use of a detailed description of a work of visual art as a literary device?
ekphrasis

In what condition does the eyelid turn outward away from the eyeball, typically due to advanced age?
ectropion

What was the former official monetary unit of the European Union that was used to evaluate the exchange rates and reserves of members of the European Monetary System on a common basis and in trading Eurobonds?
ECU

(1901--74) What American television host and journalist gave national exposure to many performers who were on their way to stardom, including Elvis Presley and The Beatles?
Ed Sullivan

Define ``edacious.''
relating to or given to eating

What yellow pressed cheese of Dutch origin---whose name comes from that of a commune in the northwestern part of the Netherlands on the IJsselmeer north-northeast of Amsterdam---is usually made in flattened balls and often coated with red wax?
Edam

Name the dish of green soybeans boiled or steamed in their pods that means ``beans on a branch'' in Japanese.
edamame

``Therefore let us lie in wait for the righteous; because he is not for our turn, and he is clean contrary to our doings: he upbraideth us with our offending the law, and objecteth to our infamy the transgressings of our education. He professeth to have the knowledge of God: and he calleth himself the child of the Lord. He was made to reprove our thoughts. He is grievous unto us even to behold: for his life is not like other men's, his ways are of another fashion. We are esteemed of him as counterfeits: he abstaineth from our ways as from filthiness: he pronounceth the end of the just to be blessed, and maketh his boast that God is his father. Let us see if his words be true: and let us prove what shall happen in the end of him. For if the just man be the son of God, he will help him, and deliver him from the hand of his enemies. Let us examine him with despitefulness and torture, that we may know his meekness, and prove his patience. Let us condemn him with a shameful death: for by his own saying he shall be respected.'' What is this from?
Wisd. 2.12--20

What does Acts 4.11 say?
This is the stone which was set at nought of you builders, which is become the head of the corner.

Who, apparently, said, ``There are five fundamental operations of arithmetic: addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, and modular forms''?
Martin Eichler

What name is given to either of two 13th-century Icelandic books, the Elder or Poetic [---] (a collection of Old Norse poems on Norse legends) and the Younger or Prose [---] (a handbook to Icelandic poetry by Snorri Sturluson), that are the chief source of knowledge of Scandinavian mythology?
Edda

(b. 1945) What Belgian racing cyclist won the Tour de France five times (1969--72 and 1974) in his professional career?
Eddy Merckx

What condition is characterized by an excess of watery fluid collecting in the cavities or tissues of the body?
edema

What order of mammals distinguished by the lack of incisor and canine teeth and native to Central and South America encompasses the anteaters, sloths, and armadillos?
Xenarthra

What is the other term for the order Xenarthra?
Edentata

(1809--49) What American short-story writer, poet, and critic --- whose fiction and poetry are Gothic in style and characterized by their exploration of the macabre and the grotesque --- wrote ``The fall of the House of Usher'' (1840), ``The murders in the Rue Morgue'' (1841), and ``The raven'' (1845)?
Edgar Allan Poe

(1869--1950) What American writer --- whose verse is collected most notably in the Spoon River anthology (1915) --- wrote biographies and novels?
Edgar Lee Masters

What Old English letter, ð or Ð, representing the dental fricatives /θ/ and /ð/, was superseded by the digraph th, but is now used as a phonetic symbol for the voiced dental fricative /ð/?
eth

Who revoked the Edict of Nantes?
Louis XIV

(1847--1931) What American inventor --- whose inventions include automatic telegraph systems, the carbon microphone for telephones, the phonograph, and the carbon filament lamp --- took out the first of more than 1,000 patents at the age of 21?
Thomas Edison

(1915--63) What French singer --- whose songs included ``La Vie en rose'' and ``Je ne regrette rien'' --- became known as a cabaret and music-hall singer in the late 1930s?
Edith Piaf

What Latin phrase refers to the first printed edition of a book?
editio princeps

(1656--1742) What English astronomer and mathematician is best known for identifying a bright comet (later named after him) and for successfully predicting its return?
Edmond Halley

Edmond Rostand

Edmund Burke

(1540--81) What English Jesuit priest and martyr's feast day is on 1 December?
St. Edmund Campion

(c. 1552--99) What English poet is best known for his allegorical romance The faerie queene (1590; 1596) that celebrated Queen Elizabeth I and was written in his eponymous stanza?
Edmund Spenser

(c. 841--870, feast day: 20 November) What king of East Anglia (855--870)---tradition holds---was captured and shot with arrows for refusing to reject the Christian faith or to share power with his pagan conqueror after the defeat of his army by the invading Danes in 870?
St. Edmund the Martyr

(c. 1175--1240, feast day: 16 November) What English churchman, teacher, and archbishop of Canterbury (1234--40) was the last primate of all of England?
St. Edmund

(1832--83) What French painter adopted a realist approach that greatly influenced the impressionists, using pure colour to give a direct unsentimental effect and noted for Déjeuner sur l'herbe (1863), Olympia (1865), and A bar at the Folies-Bergère (1882)?
Édouard Manet

Édouard Vuillard

What does ``EdP'' shorten?
eau de parfum

What does ``EdT'' shorten?
eau de toilette

What does ``EDTA'' abbreviate?
ethylenediamine tetraacetic acid

What crystalline acid with a strong tendency to form chelates with metal ions has the chemical formula (CH2COOH)2NCH2CH2N(CH2COOH)2?
EDTA

(1879--1973) What Luxembourgian-American photographer who is credited with transforming photography into an art form worked with Stieglitz in the early 1900s and was chief photographer for Vogue and Vanity Fair (1923--38) and, from 1947 to 1962, the director of photography for New York City's Museum of Modern Art?
Edward Steichen

Eduard Shevardnadze

Define ``educe.''
bring out or develop (something latent or potential)

Define ``edulcorate.''
make (something) more acceptable or palatable

Edward Williams Morley

Edward Sapir

Edwards's syndrome

Barthes (Mythologies, ``The Writer on Holiday'')

the quality or state of being very talkative

logorrhea

mandamus

invisible emanation; by-product especially in the form of waste

Define ``efflux.''
the flowing out of a particular substance or particle

radiant splendour

They are currently housed in the British Museum but are the subject of a repatriation request from the Greek government, which does not accept the legality of the Turkish sale. What is the density of the best sphere packing in 3 dimensions, conjectured by Kepler and proved by Hales?
\begin{align*}\frac{\pi}{\sqrt{18}}\end{align*}

Maryna Viazovska
